   551.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   “Person” means any person, firm, partnership, association,
corporation, company or organization of any kind.
   (b)   “Property” means discarded articles of all kinds which reasonably
appear to be discarded or of no intrinsic value. (Ord. 3256. Passed 6-23-69.)
   (c)   “Abandoned junk motor vehicle” means any motor vehicle meeting all of
the following requirements:
      (1)   Left on private property for more than seventy-two hours without
the permission of the person having the right to possession of the property, on
a public street or other property open to the public for purposes of vehicular
travel or parking, or upon or within the right-of-way of any road or highway
for forty-eight hours or longer;
      (2)   Three years old, or older;
      (3)   Extensively damaged, such damage including but not limited to any
of the following: missing wheels, tires, motor, or transmission;
      (4)   Apparently inoperable;
      (5)   Having a fair market value of $1500 dollars or less.
         (Ord. 58-98. Passed 9-21-98.)
   (d)   “Junk car” means any used vehicle propelled or intended to be
propelled by power other than human power and which is in an inoperative or a
partially dismantled condition. Portions of junk cars, such as hoods, fenders,
radiators, rims, motors, etc., not being used for the repair of a motor
vehicle, shall be considered as junk.
   (e)   In an “inoperative condition” means a vehicle propelled or intended to
be propelled under its own power.
   (f)   In a “partially dismantled condition” means a vehicle having some part
missing which is ordinarily an essential component.
(Ord. 3256. Passed 6-23-69; Ord. 80-74. Passed 10-21-74.)
   (g)   “Junk” means any machinery, equipment, apparatus, appliance, article,
or item which, by reason of its condition or placement:
      (1)   Endangers human health, life or limb or is likely to cause the
spread of disease or otherwise cause injury to the health of persons, or to
surrounding neighborhood structures;
      (2)   Is especially liable to occurrence of fire and constitutes or
creates a fire hazard;
      (3)   Causes a deteriorating and blighting influence on nearby properties
and causes depreciation in the use, enjoyment, and value of properties in the
immediately surrounding area; or
      (4)   Is ready for destruction or has been collected or stored for
salvage or conversion to some other use.
         (Ord. 61-03. Passed 11-3-03.)
   551.02 ABANDONMENT OF VEHICLES.
   No person shall abandon any vehicle and no person shall leave any vehicle at
any place for such time and under such circumstances as to cause such vehicle
reasonably to appear to have been abandoned. (Ord. 3256. Passed 6-23-69; Ord.
80-74. Passed 10-21-74.)
   551.03 STORAGE DECLARED A NUISANCE.
   Except as otherwise provided in Section
551.04, the deposit, storage, maintenance or collection of junk or junk cars
outside of a building is hereby declared to be a public nuisance and offensive
to the public health, welfare and safety of the inhabitants of this
Municipality.
(Ord. 3256. Passed 6-23-69; Ord. 80-74. Passed 10-21-74.)
   551.04 STORAGE PROHIBITED; EXCEPTION; NOTICE.
   (a)   No person in charge or control of any premises, whether as owner,
tenant, lessee, occupant or otherwise shall allow any junk or junk motor
vehicle to remain upon such premises longer than ten days after receipt of
written notice to remove the junk or junk motor vehicles from the premises,
unless they are housed in a garage or other suitable structure.
   (b)   Except in a completely enclosed building or other structure and not
visible from ground level of a public right of way or roadway, or a residential
neighbor’s property, no person shall store, park, leave, deposit, maintain,
permit, allow, or suffer to remain in a residential district within the City of
Dover any of the following:
      (1)   Any lumber or other construction materials including but not
limited to iron, galvanized, or plastic pipe or conduit, structural steel or
other metals, roofing materials, or masonry material such as brick or cement
block except for materials related to an ongoing project for which a current
building permit has been issued, and which is posted on the project location.
Firewood for private use or consumption on the premises where so stored or
maintained shall not be considered building material for the purposes of the
within subsection.
      (2)   Any machinery, equipment, household appliances or any parts
thereof, tires, refuse, other junk or salvage items.
      (3)   Any items left over from any business enterprise within or outside
the City of Dover, that results in the storage of any business related refuse,
or left over, or items removed from other locations, including, but not limited
to, stumps, trees, cut up wood, whether designated or called firewood, or not,
or any items that were removed as part of a tree trimming or removal business,
including but not limited to, sawdust, chipped wood, tree limbs, tree stumps,
cut up wood, or any of the residual items remaining and/or removed from another
premise or premises. Notwithstanding this provision, a residence may have
stored on its property, firewood for personal fireplace or heating use, but
only if stored neatly and not for more than one year’s use. It is illegal and a
violation of this section, if the items are stored or kept at any residential
premises within the City, if the items are not stored in an appropriately zoned
and permissible residential structure and cannot be seen or observed from a
public street or any other residential premises. Each day of a violation shall
be a separate violation.
      (4)   The provisions of this section, however, shall not apply to the
deposit, storage, maintenance or collection of junk or junk motor vehicles, if
safely and not stored so that a health or safety hazard is created, or stored
in violation of any state or federal homeland security or hazardous waste
statutes, in an enclosed building or in a container in a regularly established
junk yard.
   (c)   Penalty. Whoever violates this section is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor on the first offense and fourth degree misdemeanor on each
subsequent offense. (Section
551.99 for penalties for misdemeanors). (Ord. 17-16. Passed 4-18-16.)
   551.05 IMPOUNDING.
   The Chief of Police or any member of the Police Department designated by him
is hereby authorized to remove or cause to be removed any junk car remaining at
any place in violation of any provision of this chapter. Such junk car shall be
impounded until lawfully claimed or disposed of in accordance with the
provisions of Ohio R.C. 737.32 and 737.33.
(Ord. 3256. Passed 6-23-69; Ord. 80-74. Passed 10-21-74.)
   551.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: See Section
501.99 for penalties applicable to any misdemeanor classification.)
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor on a first offense. On each subsequent offense such person is
guilty of a misdemeanor of the third degree. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues.
CHAPTER 552
Sale of City Vehicles
552.01    Removal of markings required.
552.02   Responsibility of transferee.
552.03    Retroactivity.
552.99    Penalty.
 
   552.01 REMOVAL OF MARKINGS REQUIRED.
   The Director of Public Safety and the Director of Public Service are hereby
authorized to require that, as a condition to the sale of a motor vehicle owned
by the City of Dover at either public or private sale, either outright or as a
trade-in, all markings, including the name of the City of Dover must be removed
on or before the twentieth day after delivery of title to the purchaser of the
vehicle. (Ord. 61-76. Passed 7-6-76.) Penalty, see
552.99 
   552.02 RESPONSIBILITY OF TRANSFEREE.
   No person, firm or corporation purchasing a motor vehicle from the City of
Dover at either public or private sale, either outright or as a trade-in, shall
permit the name of the City of Dover or other official markings to remain on
the vehicle more than twenty days after the delivery of the title thereto.
(Ord. 61-76. Passed 7-6-76.) Penalty, see
552.99 
   552.03 RETROACTIVITY.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or corporation who has purchased
a motor vehicle from the City of Dover prior to the effective date of this
chapter to permit the vehicle to contain the name of the City of Dover or other
official markings anywhere upon said vehicle more than twenty days after
receipt of notice from the Director of Public Service that said markings or
names shall be removed. (Ord. 61-76. Passed 7-6-76.) Penalty, see
552.99
   552.99 PENALTY.
   Any person, firm or corporation violating any section of this Chapter for
which no other penalty is provided shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor.
CHAPTER 553
Parking of Commercial Motor Vehicles or Commercial Trailers on Private Property
in Residential Districts
553.01   General restrictions.
553.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Storage of junk vehicles - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
551
   553.01 GENERAL RESTRICTIONS.
   (a)   Other than for the purpose of deliveries, ongoing work by contractors
and repairmen at the site where the work is being performed, no person shall
park on private property within the residential districts of the City of Dover
an agricultural or commercial tractor or commercial trailer. For purposes of
this chapter, a commercial trailer means any vehicle without motive power that
is designed to be towed by a motor vehicle that includes, but is not limited
to, both enclosed or open cargo trailers, pole trailers, or other specific
pieces of machinery or equipment mounted on trailer axles, such as a log
splitter, cement mixer, air compressor, leaf mulcher, wood chipper, or portable
signs. Also for purposes of this chapter, an open or enclosed cargo trailer
with 2 or less axles will not be considered a commercial trailer unless the
trailer has commercial signage or lettering affixed upon it.
   (b)   For purposes of this section a “commercial vehicle” means any vehicle
used or designed to be used for business or commercial purposes which infringes
on the residential character of the residential district and includes, but not
necessarily limited to: a bus, cement truck, commercial tree trimming
equipment, construction equipment, dump truck, garbage truck, panel truck, box
truck, semi tractor, semi trailer, stage bed truck, step van, tank truck, tar
truck, tow truck, and/or commercial trailers.
(Ord. 43-11. Passed 12-5-11.)
   553.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor on the first offense. On each subsequent offense, the person is
guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree. Misdemeanor penalties stated in
Section
501.99.
(Ord. 43-11. Passed 12-5-11.)

CHAPTER 703
Regulation of Garage Sales
703.01    Definitions.
703.02    Garage sale regulations.
703.03    Permits, licenses, and fees.
703.04    Persons and sales excepted.
703.05    Penalty.
   703.01 DEFINITIONS.
   (a)    "Garage sales" shall mean and include all sales entitled "garage
sale", “lawn sale”, “attic sale”, "rummage sale," "flea market sale," "basement
sale," "porch sale," “yard sale,” or any similar casual sale of tangible
personal property which is advertised by any means whereby the public at large
is or can be made aware of the sale.
   (b)    "Person" shall mean and include individuals, families living at the
address at which a sale is to be held, partnerships, associations, and
corporations.
(Ord. 80-76. Passed 11-1-76.)
   703.02 GARAGE SALE REGULATIONS.
   (a)    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct more than four garage
sales during any twelve month period.
   (b)    No single garage sale may continue for more than four consecutive
calendar days.
   (c)    Any single garage sale may be conducted only by the occupant residing
at the address at which the sale is to be held or in conjunction with no more
than two families not residing at that address.
   (d)    Any person conducting a garage sale may sell only property
accumulated for personal use by the occupants residing at the address at which
the sale is to be held or by those persons with whom such sale is to be
conducted.
   (e)    Garage sales may be conducted only between the hours of 9 a.m. and 9
p.m. of any day. (Ord. 80-76. Passed 11-1-76.)
   703.03 PERMITS, LICENSES, AND FEES.
   (a)    The Director of Public Service may, upon written application and
payment of a fee, authorize a single garage sale to continue for more than four
consecutive days, but not more than seven consecutive days; and may permit more
than two families, but not more than six families, not residing at the address
at which the sale is to be held to participate in any single garage sale.
   (b)    Each application for a permit shall be in writing and filed with the
Director of Public Service on forms provided therefore. The information to be
filed with the Director of Public Service pursuant to this ordinance shall
include:
      (1)    The name and address of the applicant and other persons, families,
groups, associations, etc. participating in the sale.
      (2)    The location at which the sale is to be conducted.
      (3)    The number of days of the sale.
      (4)    The date and nature of any past sale.
   (c)    The fee for such permit shall be five dollars ($5.00).
   (d)    Each permit issued under this chapter must be prominently displayed
on the premises upon which the garage sale is conducted throughout the entire
period of the licensed sale. (Ord. 80-76. Passed 11-1-76.)
   703.04 PERSONS AND SALES EXCEPTED.
   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to or affect the following
persons or sales:
   (a)    Persons selling goods pursuant to an order or process of a court of
competent jurisdiction.
   (b)    Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public
officials.
   (c)    Any person selling or advertising for sale an item or items of
personal property which are specifically named or described in an advertisement
within the classified section of a local newspaper and not otherwise advertised
as a garage sale.
   (d)    Sales by a religious, charitable, or service organization, the
proceeds of which are used for religious, charitable or community service
purposes.
   (e)    Sales conducted by an auctioneer duly licensed under the laws of the
State of Ohio. (Ord. 80-76. Passed 11-1-76.)
   703.05 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provisions of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor and each day of said violation may be considered a separate
offense. (Ord. 80-76. Passed 11-1-76.)
CHAPTER 709
Billiards, Pool and Bowling Alleys
709.01   License required.
709.02    Fee.
709.03    Qualification of licensee.
709.04   Permitting minors in billiard parlor.
709.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
         See sectional history for similar State law
         Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.51
   709.01 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall establish or carry on any pool room, billiard room or
bowling alley in the City without first obtaining a license therefor, as
hereinafter provided.
(Ord. 433. Passed 5-19-19.)
   709.02 FEE.
   The Mayor shall issue a license upon personal application and the payment of
an annual license fee of five dollars ($5.00) for each pool or billiard table.
The fee for the license required by Section
709.01 pertaining to bowling alleys shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per
year for each bowling alley establishment, and a further fee of five dollars
($5.00) shall be charged for each bowling alley bed operated in such bowling
alley establishment. The Mayor shall issue the license, which license shall be
good for one year from its date, unless sooner revoked. (Ord. 2171. Passed 3-
17-53.)
   709.03 QUALIFICATION OF LICENSEE.
   No license shall be issued to any alien or to a person not of good moral
character or any person whose license has been once revoked, nor shall any
license be transferred except by the consent of the Mayor and to a person
qualified to hold a license.
   709.04 PERMITTING MINORS IN BILLIARD PARLOR.
   No owner or keeper of a billiard parlor or owner or keeper of a billiard
table at any other public place, shall permit a minor under the age of eighteen
years to play billiards or pool, or be and remain in such parlor or public
place. A minor under eighteen years of age, when accompanied by either parent
or his legal guardian, may be permitted to play both billiards and pool or be
and remain in such parlor or public place. An adult person who is in charge of
a group of minor children under the age of eighteen years may bring such group
into a billiard or pool parlor for the purpose of permitting them to play both
billiards and pool, and such group may be permitted to play both billiards and
pool or be in and remain in such parlor or public place so long as they remain
under the supervision and control of such adult person. (ORC 2903.02; Ord. 40-
65. Passed 9-7-65.)
   709.99 PENALTY.
   (a)    Whoever violates Section
709.01 shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) for a first offense
and not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for any subsequent offense.
(Ord. 433. Passed 5-19-19.)
   (b)    Whoever violates Section
709.04 shall be fined twenty dollars ($20.00) for a first offense and for each
subsequent offense, such person shall be fined fifty dollars ($50.00). In
addition to such fine, for conviction upon a second offense under Section
709.04, the license issued under this chapter shall be revoked by the Mayor and
shall not be reissued to such licensee for a period of one year from the date
of conviction.
   For the fine and costs in a prosecution under Section
709.04, the billiard table and fixtures at the place where the violation
occurred are liable on execution without exemption.
(Ord. 40-65. Passed 9-7-65.)
CHAPTER 715
Boxing and Wrestling
715.01    Permit required.
715.02    Violations.
715.99    Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Engaging in public boxing without a permit - see Ohio R.C. 3773.08
      Boxing and Wrestling Commission - see ADM. Ch.
151
   715.01 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No boxing or wrestling exhibition shall be held within the City except after
having first obtained a signed permit from the Mayor through the Boxing and
Wrestling Commission. (Ord. 1713. Passed 12-6-48.)
   715.02 VIOLATIONS.
   Any contestant who violates any of the rules and regulations laid down by
the Boxing and Wrestling Commission may be barred from further or future
participation in any public or private athletic exhibitions within the City
until clearance is obtained from the Commission, but no contestant shall be
barred by the Commission except upon a majority vote of the members duly
appointed to the Commission, except for physical reasons when the member may be
barred by the Commission's physician.
   715.99 PENALTY.
   Upon failure to obtain a permit for the holding of boxing or wrestling
exhibitions from the Mayor, such violator shall be fined not more than two
hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned not more than three months, or
both.
(Ord. 1713. Passed 12-6-48.)
CHAPTER 721
Coin-Operated Devices
721.01    Definitions.
721.02    License and registration required.
721.03    Application for license.
721.04    Issuance of license and registration sticker.
721.05    License fee.
721.06    Expiration of license.
721.07   Records of Mayor.
721.08   Obscene devices; disturbance of public.
721.09   Rules and regulations of Mayor.
721.10   Refusal to grant license; notice.
721.11   Revocation of license; notice.
721.99   Penalty.
 
CROSS REFERENCES
            Gambling - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
513
   721.01 DEFINITIONS.
   The following definitions shall be used in reference to the terms "coin-
operated amusement devices" and “coin-operated musical devices” wherever used
in this chapter.
   (a)    "Coin-operated amusement device" includes any machine or device
which, upon the insertion of a coin or token of any type in a slot or
receptacle attached to or in any way connected with the machine, operates or is
designed to operate as a game, contest or amusement, or which may be used for
any such game, contest or amusement.
   (b)    "Coin-operated musical device" includes any machine, apparatus or
device designed or constructed for the purpose of producing, reproducing or
playing any musical or vocal tone or tones or combinations of tones, made
possible by the deposit or insertion of a coin or token of any kind in a slot
or receptacle attached to the machine which operates or is designed to operate
or which may be operated for the playing of music, tones or combinations of
tone. Any auxiliary units such as speakers or booth boxes shall be considered
as part of the main machine.
   (c)    The definitions contained in this section shall not in any way be
deemed to be exclusive, and shall exclude and not be deemed to permit in any
manner any device, the possession of which is now or shall hereafter be
prohibited by law. (Ord. 1996. Passed 5-2-55.)
   721.02 LICENSE AND REGISTRATION REQUIRED.
   No person, firm, corporation, club or society shall maintain, operate, have
in possession or be permitted to maintain, operate or have in possession in or
about any premises under his or its control, which premises are open to the
public or to the membership of any club or society, any coin-operated amusement
device or coin-operated musical device, unless a license and registration for
each device shall have first been obtained by the owner thereof from the Mayor.
   "Premises which are open to the public" or similar words, as used in this
section, include clubs, private club headquarters and meeting places of
fraternal and other societies, associations and bodies, and all other public
places. (Ord. 1996. Passed 5-2-55.)
   721.03 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   Application for the license shall be made to the Mayor upon blanks to be
furnished by the Mayor for that purpose, containing the following information:
   (a)    A brief description of the coin-operated device to be registered,
including the name of the manufacturer, the factory number of the device and
the year's model.
   (b)    The name, residence and business address of the owner and the
township, city or village in which the owner resides.
   (c)   The place in the City where the coin-operated device is to be
operated.
   (d)    Whether the coin-operated device is new or used.
   (e)    Date of purchase of the coin-operated device.
   (f)   Whether the fees to be paid for the registration of the coin-operated
device during the preceding registration year, if any, have been paid.
   (g)    The nature of the business conducted at the place in the City where
the coin- operated device is to be operated.
   (h)    Such other and further information as the Mayor may require.
   Each application for registration shall be signed by the owner of the coin-
operated device or his or its authorized agent, before the Mayor. (Ord. 1996.
Passed 5-2-55.)
   721.04 ISSUANCE OF LICENSE AND REGISTRATION STICKER.
   Upon the filing of the application and the payment of the fee required by
Section
721.05, the Mayor shall issue a license to the applicant. The license shall
entitle the licensee to maintain and operate on the premises set forth and
described in the application, the device described in the application, subject
to the terms and conditions of other provisions of this chapter applicable
thereto, and also subject to such rules as may be promulgated under Section
721.09.
   At the time of issuing the license, the Mayor shall issue to the licensee a
registration tag, plate or sticker for the device described in the application,
and before the device shall be operated within the confines of the City, the
registration tag, plate or sticker shall be affixed by the owner thereof in a
conspicuous place thereon. (Ord. 1996. Passed 5-2-55.)
   721.05 LICENSE FEE.
   The annual fee for a license shall be ten dollars ($10.00). In the event
that the coin-operated device is installed subsequent to July 1 of any calendar
year, the license fee therefor shall be five dollars ($5.00). (Ord. 1996.
Passed 5-2-55.)
   721.06 EXPIRATION OF LICENSE.
   All licenses shall expire on December 31 of the year for which they were
granted. Upon the transfer of ownership of a coin-operated device, the
registration shall expire and it shall be the duty of the original owner to
immediately remove the aforementioned registration plate, tag or sticker.
Should the original owner make application for the registration of a coin-
operated device at any time during the remainder of the registration year, he
may file an application for transfer of registration accompanied by a transfer
fee of one dollar ($1.00) and the original certificate of registration. The
transfer of the registration plate, tag or sticker from the coin-operated
device for which originally issued to a coin-operated device purchased by the
same person in whose name the original registration was issued, shall be done
within a period of not to exceed ten days. No credits or unused portion of the
original registration shall be allowed. (Ord. 1996. Passed 5-2-55.)
   721.07 RECORDS OF MAYOR.
   The Mayor shall keep and maintain on file in his office a full and complete
list of all licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter, together with
a cross index showing the location of each registered device. (Ord. 1996.
Passed 5-2-55.)
   721.08 OBSCENE DEVICES; DISTURBANCE OF PUBLIC.
   No person, partnership, firm, corporation, club or society shall use or
maintain any coin-operated amusement device or coin-operated musical device, as
defined in Section
721.01, which shall play, produce, show, display or reproduce any obscene,
immoral or indecent selection, game or advertisement. No person shall use or
permit to be used or maintained, any device in any manner as to disturb the
peace and quiet of the neighborhood or of persons outside the licensed
premises, or use or display the same for purposes of wagering or gambling.
(Ord. 1996. Passed 5-2-55.)
   721.09 RULES AND REGULATIONS OF MAYOR.
   The Mayor is authorized and empowered to establish, adopt and enforce or
cause to be enforced, such rules and regulations concerning or governing the
issuance of licenses required under this chapter as he may deem reasonable and
necessary to carry out the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 1996. Passed 5-2-
55.)
   721.10 REFUSAL TO GRANT LICENSE; NOTICE.
   The Mayor is authorized and empowered to deny any application for a license
for a coin-operated machine displayed or used contrary to the terms of this
chapter. He shall notify the prospective licensee by mail, directed to the last
address of the prospective licensee, of his decision to deny the license. (Ord
1996. Passed 5-2-55.)
   721.11 REVOCATION OF LICENSE; NOTICE.
   The Mayor shall revoke the license of any licensee under this chapter who
shall violate any of the terms of this chapter, or any of the rules and
regulations established and adopted by the Mayor pursuant to Section
721.08 hereof. The Mayor shall notify the licensee by registered mail, directed
to his last address, of such revocation. (Ord. 1996. Passed 5-2-55.)
   721.99 PENALTY.
   Any person, firm, corporation, club or society who or which shall install,
maintain or operate any coin-operated amusement device or coin-operated musical
device in any public place, club or society without having first obtained a
license and registration therefor, shall be fined not less than twenty-five
dollars ($25.00) nor more than fifty dollars ($50.00). Each day that the device
is maintained, operated or displayed contrary to the provisions of this chapter
shall be deemed a separate offense. Any licensee who violates any of the terms
and conditions of this chapter or any rule or regulation of the Mayor
established and adopted under Section
721.09 hereof, shall, in addition to having his license revoked, be fined not
less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than fifty dollars ($50.00).
Any person so convicted shall not be eligible for another license for a period
of six months from the date of revocation for such offense. Each day that the
licensee violates the terms and provisions of this chapter shall be deemed a
separate offense.
(Ord. 1996. Passed 5-2-55.)

Frozen Dessert Peddlers (Repealed)

723 was repealed by Ordinance 27-20, passed September 8, 2020.)

Itinerant Vendors (Repealed)

CHAPTER 731
Peddlers, Solicitors and Canvassers
731.01    Definitions.
731.02    License or permit required and exceptions.
731.03    Application for license.
731.04    License fees.
731.05    Registration of exempt persons.
731.06    License transfer and use.
731.07   Possession and exhibition of license or permit.
731.08   Hours regulated.
731.09   Calling attention to sales by calling out, blowing horns, etc.
731.10   Harassing or annoying prospective customers; trespassing.
731.11   Revocation of license or permit.
731.12   Appeal.
731.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.61 et seq.
         Charitable solicitations - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 1716
         Frozen dessert peddlers - see BUS. REG. Ch.
723
         Itinerant vendors - see BUS. REG. Ch.
727
   731.01 DEFINITIONS.
   (a)    "Canvasser" or "solicitor", as used in this chapter, means any
individual, whether a resident of the City or not, traveling either by foot,
wagon, automobile, motor truck or any other type of conveyance, from place to
place, from house to house or from street to street, taking or attempting to
take orders for the sale of goods, wares and merchandise, personal property of
any nature whatsoever for future delivery or for services to be furnished or
performed in the future.
   (b)    "Peddler", as used in this chapter, means any person who carries with
him for the purpose of sale and immediate delivery from house to house or from
place to place, goods, wares, and merchandise. "Peddler" includes itinerant
merchants and transient vendors. Peddler excludes any person, individual, or
organization that would contact any person or organization for religious or
political purposes, or any non-commercial first amendment protected activity.
Those persons are not required to obtain a permit or license from the City of
Dover.
   Any permit or license issued to a peddler does not permit the sale of goods
otherwise regulated or prohibited by law unless a license or permit is obtained
for the sale of those goods. If a permit is required by the Tuscarawas County
Department of Health, the peddler, canvasser, or solicitor shall obtain that
permit.
   Exceptions to this definition of the term peddler, canvasser, and solicitor
are the following:
      (1)    A person making delivery of goods, wares or merchandise
theretofore sold by an establishment having a permanent place of business
within the Tuscarawas County or that otherwise has a vendor's permit issued by
the State of Ohio.
         (Ord. 27-20. Passed 9-8-20.)
   731.02 LICENSE OR PERMIT REQUIRED AND EXCEPTIONS.
   (a)    No solicitor or canvasser shall engage in business within the City
limits without first obtaining a license or permit therefor in compliance with
the provisions of this chapter, the Tuscarawas County fairgrounds, the farmer's
market held at the fairgrounds, and the farmer's market held at the Dover City
park are excluded from this chapter and the requirement to obtain a permit from
the City of Dover.
   (b)    No canvasser or peddler shall engage in business within the City
limits without first obtaining a license or permit therefor in compliance with
the provisions of this chapter.
   (c)    Charitable, civic, and philanthropic organizations, and agents or
persons employed thereby, shall be required to obtain a license as required
herein, but shall be exempt from the payment of any fees required.
   (d)    During the period of any state, national, or local declared
emergency, all solicitors and itinerant vendors shall be required to abide by
the Center for Disease Control (CDC) and the Ohio Department of Health (ODOH)
requirements and recommendations. Meeting those requirements and
recommendations will protect the citizens of Dover from needless exposures to
epidemics. Mask and face covering, as well as, other safety requirements as
recommended by the CDC and ODOH will enhance the health, safety, and welfare of
the citizens of Dover. In the event other health or safety emergencies occur,
reasonable safety and health requirements may be imposed by the administration
limited to the needs of the emergency.
(Ord. 62-62. Passed 9-17-62; Ord. 27-20. Passed 9-8-20.)
   731.03 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE.
   Application for a license shall be made to the Mayor who, upon being
furnished with sufficient proof that the applicant is of good moral character,
shall issue a license.
   Such application shall be under oath and shall include the following
information on forms to be furnished by the City:
   (a)    Name, age and description of the applicant;
   (b)    Address (legal and local, if any) and email address, and cell phone
number;
   (c)    A brief description of the nature of the business and the goods to be
sold or services to be furnished and, in the case of products of farm or
orchard, whether produced or grown by the applicant;
   (d)    If employed, the name and address of the employer, together with
credentials establishing the exact relationship, if any;
   (e)    The length of time for which the right to do business is desired;
   (f)    If a vehicle is to be used, a description of the same, together with
license number or other means of identification;
   (g)    A statement as to whether or not the applicant has pleaded guilty to
or has been convicted of any misdemeanor involving Crimen falsi or moral
turpitude, or domestic violence, and the nature of the offense, and the
punishment or penalty assessed therefor; and, any felony, unless either the
misdemeanors or felonies have been expunged pursuant to law.
   (h)    The license or permit shall allow solicitation within the city
between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m., seven days a week.
      (Ord. 62-62. Passed 9-17-62; Ord. 27-20. Passed 9-8-20.)
   
   731.04 LICENSE FEES.
   The license fee which shall be charged by the Mayor for such license shall
be as follows:
 
For one day      $ 5.00
For one week     10.00
For one month    15.00
For three months 20.00
For six months   25.00
For one year     30.00
(Ord. 62-62. Passed 9-17-62; Ord. 27-20. Passed 9-8-20.)
   731.05 REGISTRATION OF EXEMPT PERSONS.
   Any person going door to door or soliciting for religious, political, or any
first amendment protected right is exempt from these regulations.
(Ord: 62-62. Passed 9-17-62; Ord. 27-20. Passed 9-8-20.)
   731.06 LICENSE TRANSFER AND USE.
   (a)    No license shall be in any manner assignable or transferable, nor
shall any licensee authorize any person other than the one named therein to do
business, nor shall a licensee conduct any other business than is named therein
to be transacted.
   (b)    The granting of any license as provided for in this chapter shall not
be construed as giving or granting any privilege or right to the licensee of
using any public property for the display of such goods, wares or merchandise.
(Ord. 62-62. Passed 9-17-62; Ord. 27-20. Passed 9-8-20.)
   731.07 POSSESSION AND EXHIBITION OF LICENSE OR PERMIT.
   Any licensee or permittee engaged in business within the City shall carry
the license and shall produce it for examination whenever requested by any
police officer or by any prospective purchaser. The permit or license does not
permit or allow the solicitor, licensee, or permittee to remain on a person's
premises if requested to leave said premises. Notwithstanding any license or
permit granted under this ordinance, landowners, or persons in lawful
possession of lands within the City, shall have the right to refuse permission
to any licensee or permittee to enter upon that person's premises. (Ord. 62-62.
Passed 9-17-62; Ord. 27-20. Passed 9-8-20.)
   731.08 HOURS REGULATED.
   All business conducted by canvassers, solicitors and peddlers shall be
conducted solely between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 9:00 p.m., seven days a
week.
(Ord. 62-62. Passed 9-17-62; Ord. 27-20. Passed 9-8-20.
   731.09 CALLING ATTENTION TO SALES BY CALLING OUT, BLOWING HORNS, ETC.
   No person, whether he has a license, permit, or not, in going along the
streets, alleys, highways or public places of the City, shall call out, cry or
by any device make any objectionable noise or blow any horn to call attention
to the sale of any goods, wares, merchandise or any articles or things
whatsoever in a manner or by means that would constitute a nuisance under Ohio
law. (Ord. 62-62. Passed 9-17-62; Ord. 27-20. Passed 9-8-20.)
   731.10 HARASSING OR ANNOYING PROSPECTIVE CUSTOMERS; TRESPASSING.
   (a)    No peddler, solicitor or canvasser shall continue on a private
residence after being requested or notified to leave said premises; nor shall
any licensed or permitted peddler, solicitor or canvasser enter any private
house or residence without being invited to come in.
   (b)    If requested to leave by the landowner or person lawfully occupying
said premises, the permittee or licensee shall leave the premises of said
person. Failure to do so is classified as a nuisance and trespass, and is
declared to be a nuisance and trespass, and punishable as such nuisance or
trespass as a misdemeanor. Notwithstanding the right of religious or political
solicitation or proselytizing, the landowner or person lawfully in possession
of said land shall be permitted to request that person to leave. Failure to
leave shall also constitute a nuisance or a trespass, and may be punishable as
a misdemeanor.
(Ord. 62-62. Passed 9-17-62; Ord. 27-20. Passed 9-8-20.)
   731.11 REVOCATION OF LICENSE OR PERMIT.
   Any license or permit issued hereunder may be revoked by the Mayor for any
one of the following reasons:
   (a)    Violation by the applicant, his employee or agent of the provisions
of this chapter;
   (b)    Violation by the applicant, his employee or agent of any other
ordinances, or parts thereof of the City or of any State or Federal law;
   (c)    Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the
application for license;
   (d)    Fraud made in connection with his business, or
   (e)    The applicant is adjudicated to be a person not fit to be engaged in
such business.
      (Ord. 62-62. Passed 9-17-62; Ord. 27-20. Passed 9-8-20.)
   731.12 APPEAL.
   Any person aggrieved by the action of the Mayor in the denial of a license
or permit as provided in this chapter or the action of the Mayor in the
assessing of the fee as provided in Section
731.04, or the action of the Mayor in revoking a license as provided in Section
731.11, shall have the right of appeal to Council. Such appeal shall be taken
by the filing with Council, within fourteen days after notice of the action
complained of has been mailed to such person's last known address or email as
provided by applicant, a written statement setting forth fully the grounds for
the appeal. Council shall set a time and place for a hearing on such appeal and
notice of such hearing shall be given to the appellant. The decision and order
of Council on such appeal shall be final and conclusive. Time to address the
appeal shall be granted priority and be considered of the essence.
(Ord. 62-62. Passed 9-17-62; Ord. 27-20. Passed 9-8-20.)
   731.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor. Each sale or attempted sale made by any person in violation of the
provisions of this chapter shall be deemed a distinct and separate offense.
(Ord. 27-20. Passed 9-8-20.)
CHAPTER 735
Public Shows, Exhibitions and Dances
735.01   Definitions.
735.02    Permit required.
735.03    Permit application; fee.
735.04    Utility service charge.
735.99    Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.48, 715.63, 3765.02
      Intoxicating liquor in dance hall - see Ohio R.C. 4399.14
      Astrology and fortunetelling prohibited - see GEN. OFF.
517.07
      Minors curfew- see GEN. OFF. Ch.
529
      Boxing and wrestling exhibitions - see BUS. REG. Ch.
715
      Distributing handbills - see BUS. REG. Ch.
753
   735.01 DEFINITIONS.
   (a)    "Public show" or "exhibition" includes, in addition to the definition
commonly applied thereto, any circus, carnival, side show, theatrical
performance, medicine show, religious revival or exhibition which is operated
exclusively and directly for private gain or profit and which is not conducted
in a duly licensed theater or hall or pursuant to another form of license or
permit required by the City.
   (b)    "Public dance" has the same meaning as set forth in Ohio R.C.
3773.19, but shall not apply to any organization or association holding a
public dance within the City when the proceeds from such dance are not for the
personal use of the individuals of such organization or association. (Ord. 44-
64. Passed 7-6-64.)
   735.02 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   No person shall open, conduct, operate or exhibit a public show, exhibition
or public dance, as such terms are defined in Section
735.01, without first having obtained a permit therefor from the Mayor and
without having paid the permit fee as hereinafter required. Such permit shall
be posted in a conspicuous place on the premises where the public show,
exhibition or dance is held for public view. This permit shall be valid for a
period of one year after issuance.
(Ord. 44-64. Passed 7-6-64.)
   735.03 PERMIT APPLICATION; FEE.
   Any such permit herein mentioned shall be issued upon application to the
Mayor upon such forms as he may prescribe and upon payment of the sum of five
dollars ($5.00).
(Ord. 44-64. Passed 7-6-64.)
   735.04 UTILITY SERVICE CHARGE .
   No permit fee as required by this chapter shall be deemed to include any
charge of the City for water or other utility service furnished by it to any
circus, carnival or other show or exhibition. (Ord. 44-64. Passed 7-6-64.)
   735.99 PENALTY,
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor. Any such violation shall constitute a separate offense on each
successive day continued. Any person, firm or corporation found guilty of
violating a provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor misdemeanor. At
least a minimum of five dollars ($5.00) to twenty-five dollars ($25.00) is
mandatory.
(Ord. 44-64. Passed 7-6-64; Ord. 80-74. Passed 10-21-74)
CHAPTER 739
Racing Cars and Motorcycles
739.01    Race Car Inspector.
739.02    Inspection required.
739.03    Mufflers required.
739.04    Fee.
739.99    Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Operation of vehicles - see TRAF. Ch.
331
         Drag racing prohibited - see TRAF.
333.07
         Operation of motorcycles - see TRAF. Ch.
373
   739.01 RACE CAR INSPECTOR.
   There is hereby created the office of Race Car Inspector for the City, the
Inspector to be appointed by the Mayor and to serve for a period of one year.
(Ord. 1917. Passed 9-8-53.)
   739.02 INSPECTION REQUIRED.
   No firm, person or corporation shall operate or race or permit to be
operated or raced, any motorcycle, stock car, automobile or other motor vehicle
until the same is inspected and approved as being equipped with a standard
muffler of commercial manufacture, the muffler to be employed to efficiently
muffle exhaust noises from the internal combustion engine of the vehicle. The
inspection shall be made and approval shall be granted by the City Race Car
Inspector. (Ord. 1917. Passed 9-8-53.)
   739.03 MUFFLERS REQUIRED.
   All motorcycles, stock cars, automobiles or other motor vehicles used for
the purpose of racing in competition with other vehicles within the City shall
be equipped with standard mufflers of commercial manufacture, the muffler to be
employed to efficiently muffle exhaust noises from the internal combustion
engines of any vehicle. (Ord. 1917. Passed 9-8-53.)
   739.04 FEE.
   The Race Car Inspector is authorized to collect a fee for the inspection of
motorcycles, stock cars, automobiles or other motor vehicles used for the
purpose of racing in competition with other vehicles within the City, the fee
to be the sum of one dollar ($1.00), and such fee shall be paid by any person,
firm or corporation operating the motorcycle, stock car or other motor vehicle
for the purpose of racing within the City. (Ord. 1917. Passed 9-8-53.)
   739.99 PENALTY.
   Any person, firm or corporation found guilty of violating any provision of
this chapter is guilty of a minor misdemeanor. At least a minimum fine of
twenty-five dollars ($25.00) is mandatory.
(Ord. 1917. Passed 9-8-53; Ord. 80-74. Passed 10-21-74.)
CHAPTER 745
Taxicabs and Common Carriers
745.01    License required.
745.02    Inspection of vehicle.
745.03    License fee.
745.04    Medical examination for drivers.
745.05    License term.
745.06    Insurance required.
745.07   Marking; posting rates.
745.08    Parking places.
745.09    Soliciting restricted.
745.10    Schedule of rates.
745.99    Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Licensing operators - see Ohio R.C. 715.22(A), (B), 4501.01(S)
      Power to regulate rates - see Ohio R.C. 715.25
      Traffic regulations - see Traffic Code, Part Three
   745.01 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   Each and every person, firm, partnership or corporation now operating or
proposing to operate an omnibus, bus, automobile or other motor vehicle for the
transportation of persons for hire within the City and over the streets,
alleys, lanes or highways therein shall, prior to undertaking the
transportation for hire, obtain from the Mayor a license for such purpose,
applying therefor upon forms prepared by the Mayor.
   The provisions of this chapter shall include taxicabs, automobiles and buses
holding a franchise to operate within the City. (Ord. 1722. Passed 1-17-49.)
   745.02 INSPECTION OF VEHICLE REQUIRED.
   (a)    At the time that an application for a license under Section
745.01 is made by any person, firm, partnership or corporation, and prior to
the issuance of such license by the Mayor, each motor vehicle so operated or
proposed to be operated in the transportation of persons for hire under the
provisions of this chapter shall be inspected by the Police Department or
someone designated by the Department, to determine the operational safety of
such vehicle. If the vehicle is found to be safe and in proper working order, a
license may be issued upon such report to the Mayor. If the vehicle is found to
be unsafe and not in proper working order, then such defects or unsafe
conditions must be corrected before a license can be issued under the terms of
this chapter.
 
   (b)    Every person, firm, partnership or corporation operating a motor
vehicle in the City under a license issued as herein provided, must submit such
motor vehicle to police inspection at the times and places to be specified by
the Police Chief in January and July of each year. The object of such
inspection shall be to determine the operational safety of such vehicle. The
inspection shall cover tires, brakes, lights, steering apparatus and direction
signals and any condition affecting the operational safety of such vehicle. In
the event that the inspecting officer finds a defect or condition affecting
public safety, he shall certify his findings to the operator of the vehicle and
to the Mayor, and no person shall be carried for hire in such vehicle until the
defect or unsafe condition has been corrected to the satisfaction of the
officer making the inspection. During the period that the vehicle is defective
or unsafe, any license issued under this chapter for such vehicle shall be
deemed suspended. Upon finding that the condition complained of has been
corrected, the inspecting officer shall so certify such fact to the Mayor and
the motor vehicle may then be used to transport persons for hire.
   (c)    All motor vehicles licensed under this chapter shall be kept in a
safe driving condition at all times, and the Police Department shall have the
right to inspect such motor vehicles at any time it deems necessary for the
safety and welfare of the inhabitants of this City.
   (d)    In the event that a licensee or a person under his control is found
to be transporting persons for hire in a vehicle found to be unsafe by police
inspection, and after such finding has been made known to the licensee, then
the Mayor may revoke or suspend such license for not more than one year.
   (e)    A written report of the inspection shall become part of the permanent
file on each vehicle by serial number and maintained by the Mayor and Police
Department.
(Ord. 72-68. Passed 7-15-68.)
   745.03 LICENSE FEE.
   The cost of obtaining a license for any of the operations described in
Section
745.01 shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per vehicle. The fee shall be
applied to each motor vehicle so operated or proposed to be operated in the
transportation of persons for hire.
(Ord. 72-68. Passed 7-15-68.)
   745.04 MEDICAL EXAMINATION FOR DRIVERS.
   All operators and drivers of motor vehicles licensed under this chapter
shall, prior to the operation of any such vehicle, have medical examinations of
a general nature to assure the City and passengers that he or she is not
subject to seizures, fits, blackouts, does not have a heart condition or any
other ailment or disease that may cause a condition that may endanger the
passenger. A report from a practicing physician duly licensed by the State of
Ohio must be filed with the Mayor and kept on file in the permanent record
maintained in the Mayor's office. (Ord. 72-68. Passed 7-15-68.)
   745.05 LICENSE TERM.
   The licensing year of this chapter shall begin on February 1, and each
license issued shall be valid until the next succeeding February 1, at which
time all licenses shall be renewed for one year.
   The fee for licenses taken out between February 1 of any year and January 31
of the next succeeding year shall be prorated on a calendar monthly basis, the
nearest first day of a month to determine the number of months upon which the
fee shall be based.
(Ord. 1722. Passed 1-17-49.)
   745.06 INSURANCE REQUIRED.
   Any person, firm, partnership or corporation prior to transporting persons
for hire as hereinbefore described within the City, shall as a further
requirement to the obtaining of a license for the transportation, submit to the
Mayor for his approval or the approval of the Director of Law, an insurance
policy indemnifying the operator and owner against loss or injury from
negligent operation of such vehicle in the amount of not less than fifty
thousand dollars ($50,000) for property damage and not less than one hundred
thousand dollars ($100,000) for injury to one person, and not less than three
hundred thousand dollars ($300,000) for injury to more than one person. Such
insurance policy shall also provide five thousand dollars ($5,000) medical pay
per person and one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000) per person/three hundred
thousand dollars ($300,000) for more than one person for uninsured motorists
coverage. A copy of the insurance policy or a certificate of the company or
companies issuing the same shall be filed with the Mayor to become a part of
the application.
   All insurance policies required under this chapter shall be effective during
the entire period for which the license issued is effective. (Ord. 26-83.
Passed 3-21-83.)
   745.07 MARKING; POSTING RATES.
   All motor vehicles for the transportation of persons for hire and licensed
hereunder shall have suitably marked upon each side thereof the name of the
person, firm, partnership or corporation operating the same, together with the
owner's number for the cab; and in addition thereto the operator of each motor
vehicle for hire or transportation of persons for hire shall have displayed in
a prominent place with the motor vehicle a schedule of rates charged, together
with a notation thereon that a physical exam is recorded and insurance
requirements met under the seal of the City and signature of the Mayor. (Ord.
72-68. Passed 7-15-68.)
   745.08 PARKING PLACES.
   The Public Safety Director is authorized and directed to set aside and
establish such parking places on the streets of the City as in his discretion
he shall deem necessary for the use of taxicabs, buses and motor vehicles for
hire. (Ord. 1722. Passed 1-17-49.)
   745.09 SOLICITING RESTRICTED.
   No person, firm or corporation or the owner, operator or driver of taxicabs
shall solicit business in bus stations and at bus stops in the City.
   For the purpose of this chapter, "solicit" means to entreat, importune,
approach with a request, plead or implore a person who has not heretofore
contacted the owner, driver or operator of a taxicab for the purpose of
obtaining the services of the taxicab for transportation. (Ord. 1758. Passed
11-7-49.)
   745.10 SCHEDULE OF RATES.
   (a)    The rates to be charged by the operators of motor vehicles licensed
under this chapter to transport persons for hire shall be fixed by the owner
thereof immediately and the schedule thereof deposited with the Mayor, the
Police Department and Council, and such schedule published once in a newspaper
of general circulation in the City.
   (b)    Once the rates have been established pursuant to subsection (a)
hereof, such rates shall remain in effect until changed pursuant to subsection
(c) hereof, and no person being transported for hire shall be charged more than
the established rates.
   (c)    After the rates have been established pursuant to subsection (a)
hereof, any rate changes thereafter can only be made and take effect upon
compliance with the following conditions:
      (1)    Thirty days' written notice of the proposed rate changes shall be
given by the person, firm or corporation requesting such change to the Mayor,
the Police Department and Council, and published in a newspaper of general
circulation in the City at least three times before the proposed effective date
of the rate changes in an ad of at least four column inches.
      (2)    Such proposed rate changes shall be approved by both Council and
the Mayor. (Ord. 26-83. Passed 3-21-83.)
   745.99 PENALTY.
   (a)    Upon the conviction of any person, firm or corporation or the driver,
owner or operator of a taxicab of the violation of Section
745.01, such person is guilty of a minor misdemeanor on a first offense; on a
second or subsequent offense, such person is guilty of a misdemeanor of the
fourth degree.
(Ord. 1758. Passed 11-7-49; Ord. 80-74. Passed 10-21-74.)
 
   (b)   The violation of any other section of this chapter is a misdemeanor of
the third degree. (Ord. 1722. Passed 1-17-49; Ord. 80-74. Passed 10-21-74.)

CHAPTER 753
Distributing Handbills
753.01    Permit required; fee; exception for political advertising.
753.02   Advertising on vehicles, buildings, poles or structures.
753.99    Penalty.

   753.01 PERMIT REQUIRED; FEE; EXCEPTION FOR POLITICAL ADVERTISING.
   No person shall throw, cast or distribute any handbills, circulars, dodgers,
placards, samples or other advertising matter in or upon any step, door step,
porch, veranda, grounds or premises of any person, firm or corporation, or upon
the streets or alleys of the City, for the purpose of advertising any
entertainment, show, theater or wares and merchandise of any kind, unless such
person, shall have obtained a written permit from the Mayor to do so. The Mayor
may issue such permit upon the payment of a permit fee of twenty-five dollars
($25.00). The permit shall be valid for only one such distribution. However,
this chapter shall not apply to political advertising.
(Ord. 1270. Passed 6-18-34.)
   753.02 ADVERTISING ON VEHICLES, BUILDINGS, POLES OR STRUCTURES.
   No person, without the consent of the owner, shall attach, place in or affix
in any manner, advertising matter of any kind in or to any vehicle, truck or
motor vehicle, building, structure, pole, tree or surface.
(Ord. 1270. Passed 6-18-34.)
   753.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
fifty dollars ($50.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 98-66. Passed 11-7-66.)
CHAPTER 755

755.01   License required; selling unlisted goods prohibited.
755.02   Filing inventory; issuance of license.
755.03   License time limit, revocation and suspension.

755.05   Misrepresentation of sale.

CROSS REFERENCES
         Fraud - see GEN. OFF.

         Defrauding creditors - see GEN. OFF.

   755.01 LICENSE REQUIRED; SELLING UNLISTED GOODS PROHIBITED.
   No person, firm or corporation shall offer for sale or sell any merchandise
or articles not listed on the inventory filed in the office of the Mayor, as
provided in Section
755.02 or hold any sale specified by this chapter without obtaining the license
required herein. (Ord. 58-76. Passed 10-10-76.)
   755.02 FILING INVENTORY; ISSUANCE OF LICENSE.
   Every person, firm or corporation before conducting a fire sale, wreck sale,
bankruptcy sale, liquidation sale, closing out sale, going out of business sale
or similar sale shall, no less than five working days before the beginning
thereof, file in the office of the Mayor an inventory of any and all articles
intended to be sold or offered for sale at such sale. Such inventory shall
contain or have attached thereto a sworn statement that the articles contained
on such inventory constitute the actual stock in trade of the person, firm or
corporation at the premises where such person, firm or corporation has been
doing business, that such articles have been owned by such person in doing
business at such location for at least sixty days immediately preceding such
sale, and that such articles were not acquired or brought to the location of
such sale especially or purposely for such sale. Upon filing of such verified
inventory and upon the Mayor's being satisfied that the sale is bona fide as
represented, and the inventory filed is true and correct, the Mayor shall issue
a license for such sale.
(Ord. 58-76. Passed 10-10-76.)
   755.03 LICENSE TIME LIMIT, REVOCATION AND SUSPENSION.
   A license issued as set out in the preceding section shall authorize the
holding of such sale for a period of not to exceed sixty days and shall not be
renewable. A license issued hereunder may be revoked or suspended by the Mayor
upon proof of any violation of Section
755.01 to
755.05 or for the conviction of the person holding such sale of any laws of the
State or the United States or any ordinance of this City in connection with the
operation of such place of business, or upon proof of fraud in the operation of
the sale or for any misstatement in the affidavit or inventory filed. (Ord. 58-
76. Passed 10-10-76.)
   755.04 LICENSE FEE.
   Before issuing a license as required by Section
755.01 the Mayor shall demand and receive from the person applying for such
license the sum of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). (Ord. 58-76. Passed 10-10-76.)
   755.05 MISREPRESENTATION OF SALE.
   No person, firm or corporation shall represent and advertise to the public
by any means whatever the holding of a fire sale, wreck sale, closing out sale,
liquidation sale, going out of business sale, bankruptcy sale or similar sale
or make similar representations, unless such representations and advertisements
are in fact true and such sale is as represented.
(Ord. 58-76. Passed 10-10-76.)
   755.06 APPLICATION OF REGULATIONS. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
755.06 was repealed by Ordinance 4-11, passed March 7, 2011.)
   755.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor
misdemeanor. Each day's violation of this chapter shall constitute a separate
offense.
(Ord. 58-76. Passed 10-10-76.)
CHAPTER 757
Skill Game Businesses, Adult Arcades, Internet Cafes and Sweepstakes Businesses
757.01   Permit required.
757.02   Appeals.
757.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Gambling - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
550
   757.01 PERMIT REQUIRED.
   (a)   Any person, organization, or business entity who owns or operates a
skill game business, adult oriented arcade, internet gaming café, or
sweepstakes business or who desires to operate such a business shall apply
annually for a permit with the City of Dover office of the Mayor.
   (b)   Each applicant shall include with the application a certification from
the State of Ohio or an authorized testing agency which indicates that the
specific skill based amusement game machines and/or computers, internet gaming
café machines and/or computers, sweepstakes machines and/or computers, and
adult oriented arcade machines and/or computers which will be operated by the
applicant are legal to operate in the State of Ohio and are not slot machines
or other games involving a scheme of chance. Failure by the applicant to
complete the entire application shall cause the Mayor to deny the permit.
   (c)   Each applicant shall be required to list all skill based amusement
game machines and/or computers, internet gaming café machines and/or computers,
sweepstakes machines and/or computers, and adult oriented arcade machines and/
or computers being operated or to be operated by the applicant, such list to
include the following items of information:
      (1)   The make, model, and serial number of any skill based game machines
and/or computers, internet gaming café machines and/or computers, sweepstakes
machines and/or computers, and adult oriented arcade machines and/or computers.
      (2)   The hardware and/or circuit board switch settings for each machine
and/or computer operated or to be operated as a skill based, sweepstakes,
internet café, and/or adult oriented arcade machine or computer.
      (3)   The software settings of each such machine and/or computer.
      (4)   In addition to the above items, the applicant shall provide with
the permit application a copy of each manual for any such machine and/or
computer used or to be used as a skill based game machine and/or computer,
internet gaming café machine and/or computer, sweepstakes machine and/or
computer, and adult oriented arcade machine and/or computer.
   (d)   Each permit applicant shall designate a natural person or persons
responsible for the applicant’s compliance with the provisions contained in
this chapter and Ohio R.C. Chapter 2915. The owner, principal five percent (5%)
or greater shareholder, office manager, and person responsible for compliance
with this chapter and Ohio R.C. Chapter 2915 shall submit fingerprints by the
method required by the Dover Police Department. No permit shall be issued to a
convicted felon. Each applicant shall provide a copy of the lease or memorandum
of lease identifying the name, address and phone number of the lessor and
lessee of the business location or a copy of the deed if the business owner is
the owner of the business location.
   (e)   Any permit holder under this chapter shall be required to give written
notice to the Mayor of this City within fourteen (14) days of any change in any
of the information required in paragraph (c) or (d) above. Failure of any
permit holder to give the written notice required by this paragraph shall cause
the Mayor to revoke a permit issued under this chapter and shall be a violation
of this chapter that allows the imposition of the penalties listed herein.
   (f)   Applicants must apply for permits issued under this section no later
than November 1st prior to the year in which the applicant desires to operate
any of the devices, computers or machines enumerated in paragraph (c) above.
   (g)   Permits, unless revoked, shall be good for one year and shall be
effective from January 1st through December 31st of the calendar year following
the applicant’s application.
   (h)   The following permit fees are required of each applicant and must
accompany the application for each permit:
      (1)   A general permit fee of five thousand dollars ($5,000).
      (2)   An application and processing fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00)
per skill game machine and/or computer, internet café machine and/or computer,
sweepstakes machine and/or computer, and each adult oriented arcade machine
and/or computer.
      (3)   A non-refundable application fee of five hundred dollars ($500.00).
   (i)   The decision to grant, deny or revoke a permit issued under this
section shall be in the sole discretion of the Mayor.
   (j)   Each permit holder, in return for issuance of a permit under this
chapter, is subject to inspection by the Department of Police during normal
business hours to ensure the permit holder’s compliance with the provisions of
this chapter and Chapter 2915 of the Ohio Revised Code. Failure of the permit
holder to allow inspection during normal business hours shall result in
immediate revocation of the permit holder’s permit.
   (k)   Violation and/or conviction by the permit holder of any provision of
this chapter or of Ohio R.C. Chapter 2915 shall cause the Mayor to immediately
revoke a permit holder’s permit. Appeals from any permit revocation shall be
conducted in accordance with Section
757.02. Under no circumstances, including permit revocation, is a permit holder
entitled to reimbursement for permit fees, application fees, and processing
fees, and such fees are not refundable, and are not prorated to the date of
revocation or closure of a permit holder’s business.
   (l)   Skill game businesses, adult oriented arcades, internet gaming cafes,
and sweepstakes businesses shall be conditionally permitted only in B-2 and B-
3 designated districts as established in Section
1141.02 and only if in full compliance with Ohio Law and Chapter 2915 of the
Ohio Revised Code. No skill based game, adult oriented arcades, internet gaming
cafes, and sweepstakes businesses shall be located within 1,500 feet of another
business licensed under this law, within 750 feet of any church, public or
private school, park or playground, or 500 feet of any residential district.
   (m)   Criminal penalties for any violation of the provisions of this section
are governed by Section
757.99.
(Ord. 59-10. Passed 12-6-10.)
   757.02 APPEALS.
   (a)   Any permit holder in disagreement with the decision of the Mayor to
grant, deny or revoke a permit issued under this chapter may appeal that
decision to Council.
   (b)   Council may hold a hearing on the appeal at the next regularly
scheduled meeting or conduct a special session to consider an appeal. The
hearings by Council can be suspended and rescheduled at the discretion of the
President of Council. The appellant and appellee shall be permitted to present
evidence and argument. Council shall then either affirm or reverse the decision
of the Mayor. The Mayor’s decision may be reversed only by a two- thirds (2/3)
vote of Council. The decision of the Council may be appealed to the Tuscarawas
County Court of Common Pleas and the only grounds for reversal or review shall
be an abuse of discretion standard.
(Ord. 59-10. Passed 12-6-10.)
   757.99 PENALTY.   
   Violation of this chapter shall be a misdemeanor of the first degree. Each
and every day or portion of a day that the business subject to regulation by
this chapter, remains open without a permit or in violation of any provision of
this chapter, shall be a separate offense.
(Ord. 59-10. Passed 12-6-10.)
CHAPTER 759
Adult Entertainment Businesses
759.01   Purpose.
759.02   Definitions.
759.03   Zoning of Adult Entertainment Business.
759.04   Conditional use permit required.
759.05   Certain restrictions. (Repealed)
759.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Indecency and immorality - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
521
   759.01 PURPOSE.
   In order to promote the public safety, health, and welfare, the adult
entertainment businesses specifically defined herein should be subject to
regulations to prevent the erosion of the character of the surrounding
neighborhoods; and that the establishment of such businesses should be
prohibited within close proximity to existing adult entertainment businesses,
residentially zoned areas, schools, churches, parks, and playgrounds.
(Ord. 14-01. Passed 4-16-01; Ord. 59-10. Passed 12-1-10.)
   759.02 DEFINITIONS.
   The following definitions shall apply to this chapter:
   (a)   "Adult Entertainment Business" means an adult book/video store, adult
motion picture theater, adult drive-in motion picture theater, or an adult only
entertainment establishment as further defined in this section.
   (b)   "Adult Book/Video Store" means an establishment which utilizes fifteen
percent (15%) or more of its retail selling area for the purpose of retail sale
or rental, or for the purpose of display by coin or slug-operated,
electronically, electrically or mechanically controlled still or motion picture
machines, projectors, or other image producing devices, books, magazines, other
periodicals, films, tapes, and cassettes which are distinguished by their
emphasis on adult materials as defined in this section.
   (c)   "Adult Motion Picture Theater" means an enclosed motion picture
theater which is regularly used or utilizes fifteen percent (15%) or more of
its total viewing time for presenting material distinguished or characterized
by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing, or relating to adult material
as defined in this section.
   (d)   "Adult Motion Picture Drive-In Theater" means an open air drive-in
theater which is regularly used or utilizes fifteen percent (15%) or more of
its total viewing time for presenting material distinguished or characterized
by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing, or relating to adult material
as defined in this section.
       (Ord. 14-01. Passed 4-16-01.)
   (e)    "Adult Only Entertainment Establishment" means an establishment where
the patron directly or indirectly is charged a fee, and where the establishment
features entertainment or services which constitute adult material as defined
in this section, or which features exhibitions, dance routines, or gyrational
choreography of persons totally nude, topless, or bottomless, or which features
strippers or similar entertainment, or which features services which
constitute, utilize or promote adult material as defined in this section. For
purposes of the within chapter, the term “Adult Only Entertainment
Establishment” shall include any firm, business or individual engaging in the
above activities, whether said activity occurs pursuant to the normal course of
its business operations, or as an isolated or occasional incident.
      (Ord. 15-05. Passed 3-21-05.)
   (f)   "Adult Material" means any book, magazine, newspaper, pamphlet,
poster, print, picture, slide, transparency, figure, image, description, motion
picture film, video tape, phonographic record or tape, other tangible thing, or
any service capable of arousing interest through sight, sound or touch, and:
      (1)   Which material is distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on
matter displaying, describing, or representing sexual activity, masturbation,
sexual excitement, or nudity; or
      (2)   Which service is distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on
sexual activity, masturbation, sexual excitement, or nudity.
   (g)   "Bottomless" means less than full opaque covering of male or female
genitals, pubic area, or buttocks.
   (h)   "Sexual Activity" means sexual conduct or sexual contact, or both.
   (i)   "Sexual Contact" means any touching of an erogenous zone of another,
including without limitation, the thigh, genitals, buttock, pubic region, or
breast for the purpose of sexually arousing or gratifying either person.
   (j)   "Topless" means less than full opaque covering of any portion of a
female breast below the top of the nipple.
   (k)   "Church" means any structure used primarily as a church as defined in
Federal Tax Regulations, paragraph (g)(5) of 26 C.F.R. 1.6033-2 (1995).
   (l)   "School" means any public or chartered nonpublic school.
   (m)   "Park" means any property and/or structure owned or maintained by the
State of Ohio, Tuscarawas County, or City of Dover whose primary purpose and
function is to serve as a recreational facility available and open to the
general public.
   (n)   "Playground" means any recreational area owned or maintained by any
school as defined herein.
(Ord. 14-01. Passed 4-16-01; Ord. 59-10. Passed 12-6-10.)
   759.03 ZONING OF ADULT ENTERTAINMENT BUSINESS.
   Adult entertainment businesses shall be conditionally permitted only in B-
2 and B-3 designated districts as established in Section
1141.02 of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Dover.
(Ord. 14-01. Passed 4-16-01; Ord. 59-10. Passed 12-6-10.)
   759.04 CONDITIONAL USE PERMIT REQUIRED.
   (a)   No building shall be erected, constructed or developed, and no
building or premises shall be reconstructed, remodeled, arranged for use, or
used for any adult entertainment business unless authorized by the issuance of
a conditional use permit in accordance with the provisions of Title Five of
Part Eleven of the City of Dover Codified Ordinances. In addition, any adult
entertainment business shall comply with the following conditional use
criteria:
      (1)   Adult entertainment businesses shall comply with the district
regulations applicable to all properties in any district in which they are
located;
      (2)   No adult entertainment business shall be permitted in a location
which is within 1,500 feet of another adult entertainment business;
      (3)   No adult entertainment business shall be permitted in a location
which is within 750 feet of any church, public or private school, park or
playground; and
      (4)   No adult entertainment business shall be permitted in a location
which is within 500 feet of any boundary of any residential district.
         (Ord. 15-05. Passed 3-21-05.)
   (b)   In determining the minimum distance as set forth in subsection (a)(2),
above, said distance shall be measured in a straight line, without regard to
intervening structures, from the closest exterior structural wall of each such
business. The distance between any adult entertainment business and any church,
school, park, or playground, as set forth in subsection (a)(3), above, shall be
measured in a straight line, without regard to intervening structures, from the
closest exterior wall of the adult entertainment business to the closest
property line of said church, school, park, or playground. The distance between
any adult entertainment business and any residential district as established in
subsection (a)(4), above, shall be measured in a straight line, without regard
to intervening structures, from the closest exterior structural wall of the
adult entertainment business to the closest residential zoning boundary as
designated by the City of Dover Zoning Map and Codified Ordinances of the City
of Dover.
(Ord. 14-01. Passed 4-16-01; Ord. 59-10. Passed 12-6-10.)
   759.05 CERTAIN RESTRICTIONS. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
759.05 was repealed by Ordinance 4-11, passed March 7, 2011.)
 
   759.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   Any firm, business or individual found to have violated the provisions
of Section
759.04 shall be deemed guilty of a second degree misdemeanor.
 
   (b)   In addition to the penalties set forth herein, in the event of a
violation of Section
759.04, the provisions of Section
1123.11 of the Dover Codified Ordinances shall apply.
 
   (c)   Any firm, business or individual found to have violated the provisions
of Section
759.05(a), (b) or (c) shall, upon the commission of a first offense, be deemed
guilty of a fourth degree misdemeanor. Any firm, business or individual found
to have violated the provisions of Section
759.05(a), (b) or (c) shall, upon the commission of each subsequent offense, be
deemed guilty of a first degree misdemeanor.
 
   (d)   Each and every day during which a violation of the provisions of
Section
759.05(a), (b) or (c) occurs shall be deemed a separate offense.
(Ord. 15-05. Passed 3-21-05.)
