CODIFIED ORDINANCES OF DOVER
 
PART NINE - STREETS AND PUBLIC SERVICES CODE
TITLE ONE - Street and Sidewalk Areas
            Chap.
901.    Streets.
            Chap.
902.    Curbs.
            Chap.
903.    Sidewalks.
            Chap.
905.    Shade Trees.
            Chap.
910.    Right of Way Regulations.
CHAPTER 901
Streets
901.01    Paving alleys.
901.02    Definition.
901.03    Curb strip sealing prohibited.  
901.031   Entrance and exit ways from commercial and industrial uses.
901.04    Application.
901.05    Fees on petition to vacate.
901.99    Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Establishment and care of streets - see Ohio R.C. 715.19
      Municipal streets and public grounds - see Ohio R.C. 723.01 et seq.
      Damage resulting from street improvements - see Ohio R.C. 727.18 et seq.
      Design standards for streets and alleys - see P. & Z.
1109.02,
1109.03
   901.01 PAVING ALLEYS.
   (a)    (1)    On petition by owners of lots or land abutting upon any public
alley, the City may pave such alley with ODOT 404 or other suitable paving
material, such paving not to be in excess of sixteen feet in width and to a
depth of not less than three inches.
(2)    No alley shall be paved by the City under this section until there is
paid in cash, to the City by such abutting property owners, a sum equal to the
estimated cost to the City for such paving.
         (Ord. 32-93. Passed 5- 17-93.)
   (b)    In addition to the above method of alley paving, City Council may,
pursuant to an alley paving program and upon a finding that the paving of any
alley is necessary for the preservation of the health and safety of the
residents of the City, authorize the Director of Public Service to pave any
alley designated by Council at the cost of the City.
(Ord. 55-77. Passed 8-15-77.)
   901.02 DEFINITION.
   "Curb strip", as used in this chapter, means that portion of the street or
street right of way lying between the curbing and the sidewalk, or if there is
no curbing, between the edge of the paved or used portion of the street or
street right of way and the sidewalk.
(Ord. 64-63. Passed 9-3-63.)
   901.03 SEALING PROHIBITED.
   (a)   No person shall alter that portion of the surface of an existing
street or street right of way known as the curb strip without first obtaining
City approval pursuant to the procedure set forth in Section
901.04.
 
   (b)   Unless otherwise permitted pursuant to the application process
established in Section
901.04, all curb strip surfaces installed after the effective date of the
within section shall be of grass, and shall not consist of concrete, stone or
aggregate, non-organic materials, or organic materials other than grass.
(Ord. 38-05. Passed 10-17-05.)
   901.031 ENTRANCE AND EXIT WAYS FROM COMMERCIAL AND INDUSTRIAL USES.
   All existing commercial and industrial uses seeking to add a new entrance
and exit way, or change, alter and/or improve an existing entrance and exit
way, to a public street or alley from such commercial or industrial use shall
comply with Section
1109.021.
(Ord. 15-95. Passed 4-3-95.)
   901.04 APPLICATION.
   Any person, firm or corporation desiring to obtain permission pursuant to
Section
901.03(a) or (b), to alter an existing curb strip, or to install a curb strip
consisting of something other than grass, shall first obtain a permit from the
City in accordance with the following:
   (a)   The party so desiring said alteration or installation shall make
application to the City stating the reason or reasons for the purported
alteration or installation, which shall be accompanied by a map or drawing
showing the area involved.
   (b)   In the case of a request for the alteration of an existing curb strip
or the installation of a non-grass curb strip in an area designated by Section
1131.01 as an R-1, R-2, R-3 or R-4 zoning use district, the application shall
be presented to City Council, which shall investigate such application. Council
shall grant any such application only if it finds that such alteration or
installation will not interfere with existing or future utilities, that it is
necessary or proper, and that it is in the best interest of the Municipality.
Council’s determination to grant any such application shall be done by
resolution. Such resolution must obtain the affirmative vote of a majority of
the elected members of Council, but need not be published.
 
   (c)   In the case of a request for the alteration of an existing curb strip
or the installation of a non-grass curb strip in an area designated by Section
1131.01 as a B-1, B-2, B- 3, M-1 or M-2 zoning use district, the application
shall be presented to the Director of Public Service, who shall investigate
such application. The Director of Public Service shall grant any such
application only if he finds that such alteration or installation will not
interfere with existing or future utilities, that it is necessary or proper,
and that it is in the best interest of the Municipality.
(Ord. 38-05. Passed 10-17-05.)
   901.05 FEES ON PETITION TO VACATE.
   Any person requesting the vacation, narrowing or abandonment of any street,
alley, easement or other public property or parts thereof, shall first file a
petition with the Clerk of Council setting forth a complete description of the
property proposed to be vacated, narrowed or abandoned, together with an
accurate map thereof and such other facts as required by State law or City
ordinances, together with a fee in the sum of seventy-five dollars ($75.00),
unless such petition is accompanied by a written consent as provided for in
Ohio R.C. 723.06, in which event the fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) to
cover all expenses incident thereto. Such fee shall be deposited and credited
to the General Fund of the City, and shall constitute a complete fee for such
proceedings. (Ord. 6-67. Passed 2-6-67.)
   901.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
fifty dollars ($50.00). Any such violation shall constitute a separate offense
on each successive day continued.
(Ord. 64-63. Passed 9-3-63.)
CHAPTER 902
Curbs
902.01   Placement.
902.02   Type and size.
902.03   Materials.
902.04   Location.
902.05   Downspouts.
902.06   Permit to construct.
902.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Subdivision design standards - see P. & Z. Ch.
1109
   902.01 PLACEMENT.
   Curbs shall be placed with the face of the curb at the edge of the
designated pavement width of the streets. The curbs shall be constructed to the
grades that have been established by the approved and/or accepted plans for
individual streets, or shall be in accordance with the existing street grades
and the accepted typical streets cross section where no approved and/or
accepted plan exists. Survey stakes for placement of curbs shall be provided by
the City at the request of the adjacent lot owner; except in new subdivisions
survey stakes shall be provided by the subdivision developer. (Ord. 25-91.
Passed 5-6-91.)
   902.02 TYPE AND SIZE.
   (a)   In all new streets, curbs shall be the curb and gutter type with the
cross section of the curb and gutter conforming to the following requirements:
      (1)   The gutter width shall be eighteen inches.
      (2)   The gutter shall slope upward from the face of the curb at a slope
of one- half inch per one foot.
      (3)   The thickness of the gutter shall be a minimum of six inches.
      (4)   The height of the curb shall be six inches above the gutter.
      (5)   The width of the curb shall be six inches.
      (6)   The face of the curb shall be perpendicular to the street with a
rounded top edge, and shall not slope.
      (7)   The back of the curb and gutter shall have a minimum height of
twelve inches.
   (b)   In existing streets where the existing curbs are the straight type and
with no gutter, new curbs may be the straight type conforming to the following
requirements:
      (1)   The width of the curb shall be six inches.
      (2)   The face of the curb shall be perpendicular to the street with a
rounded top edge, and shall not slope.
      (3)   The depth of the curb shall be eighteen inches.
         (Ord. 25-91. Passed 5-6-91.)
   (c)   The Director of Public Service may allow an exception to the above
requirements stated in subsections (a) and (b) where curbs are directly
adjacent to sidewalks. In lieu of the curb or the curb and gutter being poured
separately from the sidewalk, the Director of Public Service may allow the curb
to be poured integrally with the sidewalk. If such is allowed, the construction
shall conform to the following requirements.
      (1)   The face of the curb shall be perpendicular to the street with a
rounded edge, shall have a depth of twelve inches and shall have its top eight
inches finished.
      (2)   The bottom width of the curb shall be twelve inches before it
slopes upward at a forty-five degree angle to the bottom of the walk slab.
      (3)   The top of the combined curb and sidewalk slab shall be scored six
inches back from the face of the curb in order to simulate a six inch wide
curb.
      (4)   The combined curb and sidewalk shall be reinforced with a 4 x 4/6 x
6 welded wire mesh. (Ord. 45-99. Passed 8-2-99.)
   902.03 MATERIALS.
   All curbs shall be constructed of concrete with a #8 limestone aggregate.
The concrete shall have a minimum compressive strength of twenty-eight days
equal to 4,000 pounds per square inch. Other materials for curbs, as bituminous
concrete (asphalt) or wood are not permitted.
(Ord. 25-91. Passed 5-6-91.)
   902.04 LOCATION.
   (a)   Curbs shall be required on both sides of all streets in new
subdivisions and on existing streets; except, streets that are permitted to
have ditches for drainage purposes are not required to have curbs. Construction
of the curbs shall occur when the streets are being installed, or in the case
of existing streets where curbs do not exist, construction shall occur when new
buildings are being built on lots or parcels of land adjacent to a street;
except, construction of curbs may be waived by the Service Director where fifty
percent (50%) of the lots fronting on a street within that block do not have
curbs, and where no public purpose would be served by the construction of
curbs. (Ord. 25-91. Passed 5-6-91.)
   (b)   Construction of curbs shall occur no later than twelve months from the
date of the issuance of a building permit in the case of existing streets.
(Ord. 58-07. Passed 11-5-07.)
   902.05 DOWNSPOUTS.
   Provisions shall be made in all new curbs to accept the storm drainage from
downspouts by installing a short section of standard downspout pipe having a
nominal size of three inches by four inches. The section of downspout pipe
shall be installed in the curbs so that its height is three inches and shall be
installed when the curb is constructed. Cutting of the curbs for installation
of storm drainage pipes after the curb has been constructed shall be
prohibited. (Ord. 25-91. Passed 5-6-91.)
   902.06 PERMIT TO CONSTRUCT.
   The adjacent lot owner or curb contractor shall obtain a permit to install a
new curb before the curb is constructed. The cost of the permit shall be five
dollars ($5.00) and shall be obtained from the Building and Zoning Codes
Administrator. This requirement does not apply to subdivision developers who
are constructing such under other parts of these Ordinances. It does apply to
lot owners or curb contractors that are removing and replacing existing curbs.
(Ord. 25-91. Passed 5-6-91.)
   902.99 PENALTY.
   Lot owners or curb contractors who fail to comply with any provision of this
chapter are subject to a two hundred dollar ($200.00) fine for the violation of
each provision of this chapter.
(Ord. 25-91. Passed 5-6-91.)
CHAPTER 903
Sidewalks
903.01    Placement.
903.02    Lateral slopes.
903.03    Materials.
903.04    Size.
903.05    Location.
903.06    Decorative. (Repealed)
903.07    Handicap ramps.
903.08    Permit to construct.
903.99    Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Sidewalks and gutters - see Ohio R.C. 729.01 et seq.
      Sidewalk obstructions and cleaning - see GEN. OFF.
517.04,
517.06
   903.01 PLACEMENT.
   Sidewalks shall be placed with the inside edge on the property line of the
street and the lot, and sloped laterally towards the street. The sidewalks
shall be constructed to the grades that have been established by the approved
and/or accepted plans for individual streets, or shall be in accordance with
the existing street grades and the accepted typical street cross section where
no approved and/or accepted plan exists. Survey stakes for placement of
sidewalks shall be provided by the City at the request of the adjacent lot
owner; except, in new subdivisions survey stakes shall be provided by the
subdivision developer. (Ord. 24-91. Passed 5-6-91.)
   903.02 LATERAL SLOPES.
   All sidewalks constructed or repaired in the City shall be laid flat and not
rounded. In Residential Districts, such sidewalks shall have not more than one-
quarter inch rise per foot from the outside edge of the sidewalk or street side
to the inside or property side of such sidewalk. In Commercial and Industrial
Districts, such sidewalks shall have not more than a one-half inch rise per
foot from the outside edge of the sidewalk or street side to the inside or
property side of such sidewalk. (Ord. 24-91. Passed 5-6-91.)
   903.03 MATERIALS.
   All sidewalks shall be constructed of concrete with a #8 limestone
aggregate. The concrete shall have a minimum compressive strength at twenty-
eight days equal to 4,000 pounds per square inch. Other materials for
sidewalks, such as bituminous concrete (asphalt) are not permitted. Ingredients
added to the concrete mixture to change its natural color are prohibited. (Ord.
24-91. Passed 5-6-91.)
   903.04 SIZE.
   All sidewalks shall have a minimum thickness of four inches, except at alley
approaches the thickness shall be eight inches and at drive approaches the
thickness shall be six inches. The width of sidewalks shall match the width of
adjacent sidewalks in the street. In new streets, that are not continuations of
existing streets, sidewalks shall have a minimum width of four feet. (Ord. 24-
91. Passed 5-6-91.)
   903.05 LOCATION.
   (a)   Sidewalks shall be required on both sides of all streets in new
subdivisions and on existing streets that are being extended. Construction of
the sidewalks shall occur when buildings are being built on the lots or parcels
of land. Sidewalks shall also be required on all existing streets within the
City when new buildings are being built on lots or parcels of land adjacent to
the street; except, construction of sidewalks may be waived by the Service
Director where fifty percent (50%) of the lots fronting on a street within that
block do not have sidewalks, and where no public purpose would be served by the
construction of sidewalks.
(Ord. 24-91. Passed 5-6-91.)
   (b)   (1)   Construction of sidewalks shall occur no later than twelve
months from the date of the issuance of a building permit unless extended by
the zoning inspector for a reasonable period of time not to exceed an
additional twelve months for good cause.
      (2)   In all new subdivisions and on existing streets that are being
extended sidewalks shall be installed no later than three years from the date
of the filing of the plat by the developer or the landowner unless extended for
a reasonable period of time not to exceed two years by the building and zoning
inspector for good cause.
         (Ord. 58-07. Passed 11-5-07.)
   903.06 DECORATIVE. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
903.06 was repealed by Ordinance 27-13, passed June 17, 2013.)
   903.07 HANDICAP RAMPS.
   Handicap ramps at all City street intersections shall be installed in new
sidewalks or those being removed and replaced. The ramp shall conform to the
design that the City has established and used for handicap ramps.
(Ord. 48-06. Passed 11-20-06.)
   903.08 PERMIT TO CONSTRUCT.
   The adjacent lot owner or sidewalk contractor shall obtain a permit to
install a new sidewalk before the sidewalk is constructed. The cost of the
permit shall be five dollars ($5.00) and shall be obtained from the Building
and Zoning Codes Administrator. This requirement does not apply to subdivision
developers who are constructing such under other parts of these Ordinances. It
does apply to lot owners or sidewalk contractors that are removing and
replacing existing sidewalks.
(Ord. 24-91. Passed 5-6-91.)
   903.99 PENALTY.
   Lot owners or sidewalk contractors who fail to comply with any provision of
this chapter shall be fined up to two hundred dollars ($200.00) for the
violation of each provision of this chapter.
(Ord. 24-91. Passed 5-6-91.)
CHAPTER 905
Shade Trees
905.01   Shade Tree Commission.
905.02   Term of office.
905.03   Compensation.
905.04   Powers and duties.
905.05   Planting permit required, removal of tree improperly planted.
905.06   Replacement trees.
905.07   Interference with tree activities.
905.08   Protection of trees.
905.09   Placing materials on public property.
905.99   Penalty.
   
CROSS REFERENCES
      Power to regulate shade trees and shrubbery - see Ohio R.C. 715.20
      Assessments for tree planting or maintenance - see Ohio R.C. 727.011
      Weeds, trees and grasses - see GEN. OFF. Ch.
549
   905.01 SHADE TREE COMMISSION.
   There is hereby created and established a Shade Tree Commission for the
City, which Commission shall consist of the following nine members: the
Director of Public Service, the City Engineer, the Chairman of the Parks and
Recreation Committee of Council, the City Tree Manager, and five persons,
citizens and residents of this City, who shall be appointed by the Mayor with
the approval of Council.
(Ord. 67-94. Passed 10-3-94.)
   905.02 TERM OF OFFICE.
   The term of the five persons to be appointed by the Mayor shall be three
years, except that the term of two of the members appointed to the first
Commission shall be only one and two years respectively. In the event that a
vacancy shall occur during the term of any member, his successor shall be
appointed for the unexpired portion of such term.
(Ord. 84-68. Passed 8-5-68; Ord. 2-92. Passed 1-20-92.)
   905.03 COMPENSATION.
   Members of the Shade Tree Commission shall serve without compensation.
(Ord. 84-68. Passed 8-5-68.)
   905.04 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   (a)   The Shade Tree Commission shall have the power to study, investigate,
plan, advise, report and recommend to Council, the Director of Public Service
or the Mayor any action, program, plan or legislation which the Commission
shall find or determine to be necessary or advisable for the care,
preservation, trimming, planting, replanting, maintaining, protecting,
promoting, removal or disposition of trees and shrubs in public ways, curb
strips, streets, alleys and all City property.
   (b)    The Commission shall choose its own officers, make its own rules and
regulations and keep a journal of its proceedings. A majority of the members
shall be a quorum for the transaction of business. All plans, findings, advice,
reports and recommendations made by the Commission shall be in writing and
shall designate by name those members of the Commission approving or concurring
therein, and members who do not so approve or concur therein shall have the
right, as a part of such report, to state their reasons for refusing to approve
or concur.
   (c)    The Commission, when requested by Council, the Mayor or the Director
of Public Service, shall consider, investigate, make findings, report and
recommend upon any special matter or question coming within the scope of its
work. (Ord. 27-84. Passed 6-4-84.)
   (d)    The Service Director, upon consultation with the Dover Shade Tree
Commission, shall have power to promulgate and enforce rules, regulations and
specifications concerning trimming, spraying, removal, planting, pruning and
protection of trees, shrubs, vines, hedges and other plants upon the right of
way of any street, alley, sidewalk, or other public place in the City. (Ord.
34-90. Passed 5-7-90.)
   905.05 PLANTING PERMIT REQUIRED, REMOVAL OF TREE IMPROPERLY PLANTED.
   (a)    No person shall hereafter plant any tree or shrub upon any public
way, curb strip, street, alley or municipal property unless he shall have first
obtained a permit in writing from the Director of Public Service specifying the
size, type, species and location on the public way, curb strip, street, alley
or municipal property of the tree or shrub so to be planted. Approval to plant
requires adherence to the specifications of the Shade Tree Commission and the
ordinances of the City of Dover including but not limited to Section
1123.05.
(Ord. 34-90. Passed 5-7-90.)
   (b)    The Director of Public Service shall have the authority to deny a
permit to any person who proposes to plant any tree or shrub upon a public way,
curb strip, street, alley or Municipal property of a size, type or species
found to be undesirable by the Commission or so found to be undesirable for the
location proposed; or he may deny a permit to any person who proposes to plant
any tree or shrub upon a public way, curb strip, street, alley or Municipal
property if at a location found by the Commission to be of a size or type
unsuitable for planting of trees or shrubs.
   (c)    Whenever any tree shall be planted in the public way, curb strip,
street, alley or Municipal property in conflict with specifications of the
Shade Tree Commission, it shall be lawful for the City to remove or cause
removal of the same, and the exact cost thereof shall be assessed to the person
responsible for the planting as provided by law in the case of special
assessments.
   (d)    Trees planted upon a public way, curb strip, street, alley or
Municipal property may be removed by the City as necessary to protect the
public health, safety, welfare and aesthetics. The Director of Public Service
may cause the removal of any such tree by using City employees, Shade Tree
Commission members, or private contractors under contract with the City. (Ord.
27-84. Passed 6-4-84.)
   (e)    No person shall engage in the business of planting, cutting,
trimming, pruning, removing, spraying or otherwise treating trees, within the
City without first having obtained a license, which license shall be issued
according to the following standards:
      (1)    Such license shall be issued upon the presentation of evidence
satisfactory to the Mayor after a recommendation from the Shade Tree
Commission, that the applicant is qualified and has the experience and training
to engage in tree trimming, tree removal and tree surgery work for hire; that
the applicant agrees to comply with the specifications for tree trimming, tree
removal and tree surgery work for hire; and provided that before any license
shall be issued, each applicant shall first file evidence of possession of
liability insurance in the minimum amounts of three hundred thousand dollars
($300,000) for bodily injury or death and one hundred thousand dollars
($100,000) property damage indemnifying the City or any person injured or
damaged resulting from the pursuit of such endeavor as herein described.
      (2)    A fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be charged for each such
license, giving such licensee the right to engage in tree trimming, tree
removal and tree surgery for the period of one year next following the issuance
of such license.
      (3)    The Mayor is authorized to revoke a license at any time upon proof
satisfactory to him that the person holding such license is violating the
provisions of this section or the specifications of the Shade Tree Commission
for tree trimming, tree removal or tree surgery for hire; or is engaged in
practicing fraud upon any person for whom he is performing tree trimming, tree
removing or tree surgery for hire within the City.
   (f)    No street trees other than those species authorized by the
regulations promulgated hereunder may be planted under or within ten lateral
feet of any overhead utility wire, or over or within five lateral feet of any
underground water line, sewer line, transmission line or other utility.
   (g)    It shall be unlawful as a normal practice for any person, firm or
City department to top any tree, park tree or other tree on public property.
Topping is defined as the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs larger than
three inches in diameter within the tree's crown to such a degree so as to
remove the normal canopy and disfigure the tree. Trees severely damaged by
storms or other causes, or certain trees under utility wires or other
obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical may be exempted from
this subsection at the determination of the Shade Tree Commission.
(Ord. 34-90. Passed 5-7-90; Ord. 49-97. Passed 10-6-97.)
   905.06 REPLACEMENT TREES.
   Any person or property owner granted permission to remove a tree from the
City streets or properties for the purpose of construction shall replace the
removed tree or trees according to the specifications of the Shade Tree
Commission. The person or property owner shall bear the cost of replacing all
trees removed. (Ord. 27-84. Passed 6-4-84.)
   905.07 INTERFERENCE WITH TREE ACTIVITIES.
   No person shall hinder, prevent, delay or interfere with the Director of
Public Service or his designated representative while engaged in carrying out
the execution or enforcement of this chapter; provided, however, that nothing
herein shall be construed as an attempt to prohibit the pursuit of any remedy,
legal or equitable, in any court of competent jurisdiction for the protection
of property rights by the owner of any property within the Municipality.
(Ord. 27-84. Passed 6-4-84.)
   905.08 PROTECTION OF TREES.
   (a)   All trees on any street or other publicly owned property near any
excavation or construction of any building, structure or street work, shall be
guarded with a good substantial fence, frame or box not less than four feet
high and eight feet square, or at a distance in feet from the tree equal to the
diameter of the trunk in inches D.B.H., whichever is greater, and all building
material, dirt or other debris shall be kept outside the barrier.
   (b)   No person shall excavate any ditches, tunnels, trenches or lay any
drive within a radius of ten feet from any public tree without first obtaining
a written permit from the Director of Public Service.
   (c)   Upon the discovery of any destructive or communicable disease or other
pestilence which endangers the growth or health of trees, or threatens to
spread disease or insect infestations, the City Forester shall at once cause
written notice to be served upon the owner of the property upon which such
diseased or infested tree is situated, and the notice shall require such
property owner to eradicate, remove or otherwise control such condition within
a reasonable time to be specified in such notice.
   (d)   The provisions of Section 1187.04 (d)(1) as they relate to the
preservation of existing trees within new developments are hereby incorporated
and, by this section shall apply to all existing trees presently existing
within the City whether located within a new development or otherwise.
(Ord. 34-90. Passed 5-7-90.)
   (e)   During the planning stage of any project in the City which would
impact any public trees, either the office of the Director of Public Service,
or the office of the City Consulting Engineer shall notify the Chairperson of
the Dover Shade Tree Commission. Upon notification, the Chairperson shall
review said plans, and make recommendations concerning the tree(s) to be
involved, which recommendations shall be considered prior to implementation of
the project. (Ord. 50-97. Passed 10-6-97.)
   905.09 PLACING MATERIALS ON PUBLIC PROPERTY.
   (a)   No person shall deposit, place, store or maintain upon any public
place of the City, any stone, brick, sand, concrete or other minerals which may
impede the free passage of water, air and fertilizer to the roots of any tree
growing therein, except by written permit of the Director of Public Service.
   (b)   Section
311.01 of the Traffic Code shall apply to all tree trimming, tree removal or
tree surgery performed by any person within the City.
   (c)   No person subject to the provisions of Section
905.05(e) shall engage in the business of tree trimming, tree removal or tree
surgery on Sunday.
   (d)    No person in the City shall conduct any tree trimming, tree removal
or tree surgery on Sunday, or where the branches or tree limbs would, in
falling, block a street or alley.
   (e)    Emergency work may be done on trees damaged by lightning, storms or
other acts of God, by permission of the Director of Public Service, who must
first be notified when any street or other thoroughfare is to be blocked by
tree trimming, tree removal, or tree surgery.
(Ord. 34-90. Passed 5-7-90.)
   905.99 PENALTY.
   (a)    Violations. Any person who violates any provision of this chapter or
who fails to comply with any notice issued pursuant to the provisions of this
chapter, upon being found guilty of violation, shall be subject to a fine not
to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each separate offense. Each day
during which any violation of the provisions of this chapter shall occur or
continue shall be a separate offense. If, as a result of the violation of any
provision of this chapter, the injury, mutilation or death of any tree, shrub,
or other plant located on City owned property is caused, the cost of repair or
replacement of such tree, shrub or other plant shall be borne by the party in
violation. The replacement value of trees and shrubs shall be determined in
accordance with the latest revision of "A Guide to the Professional Evaluation
of Landscaped Trees, Specimen Shrubs and Evergreens" as published by the
International Society of Arboriculture.
   (b)    Assessment of Claim. In the event that a public nuisance is not
abated by the date specified in any notice, sent under this chapter, the City
Forester is authorized to cause the abatement of such nuisance. The reasonable
cost of such abatement shall be filed as a lien against the property on which
the nuisance was located. In addition, the owner of the property upon which the
nuisance was located shall be subject to the fines assessed as a result of
criminal prosecution under subsection (a) hereof.
(Ord. 34-90. Passed 5-7-90.)
CHAPTER 910
Right of Way Regulations
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Pursuant to Ordinance 64-97, passed January 5, 1998, the City
has enacted a comprehensive right of way ordinance. Copies are on file at City
Hall.

CHAPTER 920
Availability of Utility Services
920.01   City policy.
920.02   Present provider.
920.03   Future connections.
920.04   Other providers.
920.05   Scope.
920.06   Implementation of chapter.
   920.01 CITY POLICY.
   It is hereby declared to be the policy of the City of Dover to make
available the products and services of its municipal utilities to all residents
and taxpayers of the City of Dover, in accordance with such rates, rules,
regulations and other terms and conditions of service as are now, or may
hereafter be, adopted by the City of Dover, at reasonable rates and without
undue discrimination taking into account customer situation, classification,
usage and other appropriate factors. (Ord. 45-98. Passed 7-6-98.)
   920.02 PRESENT PROVIDER.
   There is presently no provider of electric, water or sewer utility service,
other than the City of Dover and its utility departments, that is authorized by
the City of Dover under Article XVIII of the Ohio Constitution to provide such
utility services within the corporate limits of the City of Dover. (Ord. 45-98.
Passed 7-6-98.)
   920.03 FUTURE CONNECTIONS.
   On and after the effective date of this section, all new utility service
connections for electric, water or sewer utility service within the corporate
limits of the City of Dover, as the same may be altered from time to time
through annexation or otherwise, shall be made with the City of Dover’s
electric, water and sewer utilities unless and until any other entity desiring
to provide such service obtains a franchise or like permit from the City of
Dover setting forth the terms and conditions under which it may operate or
serve consumers within the City of Dover. Service from facilities existing as
of the effective date of this section by a provider of utility service to a new
occupant of a premise served on the effective date of this section shall not be
precluded by this section.
(Ord. 45-98. Passed 7-6-98.)
   920.04 OTHER PROVIDERS.
   This chapter shall not affect utility service connections and arrangements
between individual residents or other consumers within the City of Dover and
providers of utility services other than the City of Dover, if such
arrangements are lawful, existing and in place as of the effective date of this
chapter. Such arrangements and connections are hereby permitted to continue, at
the option of such residents having such arrangements and connections, unless
the City of Dover obtains such authorization or approval as may be required
under the laws of the State of Ohio to cause such existing arrangements and
connections to be terminated and utility service provided by the City of Dover
or other franchised providers to be substituted for service provided under such
other arrangements and connections.
(Ord. 45-98. Passed 7-6-98.)
   920.05 SCOPE.
   Nothing in this chapter is to be construed to limit either the rights or the
authority of the City of Dover under the laws and Constitution of Ohio,
including the right to sell utility products and services outside its corporate
limits. (Ord. 45-98. Passed 7-6-98.)
   920.06 IMPLEMENTATION OF CHAPTER.
   (a)   The Law Director is hereby authorized and directed to initiate, in
consultation with the Mayor, such applications and other proceedings before the
courts and administrative agencies of the State of Ohio as may be necessary and
appropriate to obtain any and all orders or other relief required to effectuate
the purposes of this chapter.
   (b)   The Mayor is hereby authorized to negotiate and present to Council for
its approval reasonable franchise or like agreements with any entity desiring
to operate or provide electric, water or sewer utility service to consumers
with the City of Dover.
(Ord. 45-98. Passed 7-6-98.)
CHAPTER 921
Temporary Utility Services; Termination
921.01   Utilities for tentatively approved annexations.
921.02   Terminating utility service.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Water service outside City limits - see S. & P.S.
925.03
      Sewage service outside City limits - see S. & P.S.
927.03
   921.01 UTILITIES FOR TENTATIVELY APPROVED ANNEXATIONS.
   Temporary hook-ups or connections for City utilities, including water
supply, sewage and sewage disposal service operated by the City, may be
provided for building purposes and convenience of those persons temporarily
residing in a territory for which an application has been approved by the
County Commissioners for annexation to the City. In the event the application
for annexation is refused, then such utilities shall be terminated not later
than one week after such determination of refusal.
(Ord. 2243. Passed 4-6-59.)
   921.02 TERMINATING UTILITY SERVICE.
   (a)   A penalty of five percent (5%) will be applied to all unpaid water,
sewer, electric, and refuse accounts fifteen days after the billing date. Net
due amount shown on the bill will be accepted for one full day following the
net due date at the City Utilities Office, Third Street, Dover, for payments
that are mailed by the net due date, payments made at local banks which are
stamped “PAID” by the due date, and in person at the counter.
   (b)   At the same time that penalties are applied, overdue notices are sent
allowing seven business days for payment of the current due amount plus
penalties. This notice includes, but is not limited to, a date after which
service may be terminated if payment is not made, the customer’s name, account
number and the amount that must be paid to avert termination of service (no
less than the current amount plus penalties).
   (c)   Terminations of service for nonpayment of utility bills shall be
carried out on the Monday or Tuesday morning following elapse of the time
allowed to pay at least the current amount plus penalties.
   (d)    On the day that water or electric service is to be discontinued for
nonpayment, water division and/or electric field division personnel will
terminate utility service to the residence/account and leave written notice in
the form of a brightly-colored card or door hanger that water or electric
service has been discontinued for nonpayment. This card/door hanger shall
include the telephone number of the City Utility Billing Office, and the hours
during which the Utility Billing Office is open for business. The card/door
hanger shall be left in a conspicuous location.
   (e)    Once utility service has been terminated for nonpayment, service will
not be restored until payment of the entire account balance has been made in
full. The account holder must also pay any re-connection fees.
   (f)    Arrangements to pay made by recognized social agencies, religious
organizations or firms retained to manage a customer's affairs will avert
immediate disconnection.
   (g)    Customers of the City Utility Office who feel that their utility
service is designated for termination of service for nonpayment in error, or
customers who wish to protest the decision by the Utility Billing Office
manager to terminate utility service for nonpayment, may request a hearing by
calling the Utility Billing Office prior to the service termination.
(Ord. 59-92. Passed 9-21-92.)
CHAPTER 923
Sewer and Water Connections and Construction
923.01   Sanitary sewer connection permit required.
923.02   Sanitary sewer construction charges.
923.03   Street opening charges for sewer lateral connections.
923.04   Minimum sewer connection permit fee.
923.05   Private construction of sewer mains; reimbursement.
923.06   City construction of sanitary sewers; charges.
923.07   Denial of sewer extension requests.
923.08   Sanitary sewer laterals.
923.09   Water permit required.
923.10   Water line construction costs.
923.11   Service line and street opening charges for water service line.
923.12   Water meters.
923.13   Private construction of water lines; reimbursement.
923.14   City construction of water lines; charges.

   923.01 SANITARY SEWER CONNECTION PERMIT REQUIRED.
   In order to install a sanitary sewer lateral and to connect to the City
sanitary sewer system, or to replace an existing sanitary sewer lateral, it
shall be necessary to obtain a sewer permit from the Director of Public
Service, who shall issue a sewer permit to licensed plumbing contractors only
upon the payment of the fees in Sections
923.02 and
923.03 for each connection to the City sanitary sewer collection system.
(Ord. 54-88. Passed 9-26-88.)
   923.02 SANITARY SEWER CONSTRUCTION CHARGES.
   The Director of Public Service shall make the following permit charges where
no previous fee of any type has been paid by the present or former property
owner for such sewer:
   (a)    Dwellings.
 
Homes (all)      per home    $650.00
Apartments (all) per unit    650.00
Trailers         per trailer 650.00
    (b)    Commercial Industrial etc.
 
Industrial buildings (domestic waste only)          per employee       $ 133.00
Retail business                                     per employee       133.00
Office buildings                                    per employee       133.00
Motel                                               per unit           265.00
Service station/car wash                            per each           5,312.50
Gas station/convenience store                       per employee       133.00
Assembly halls                                      per seat           21.50
Churches                                            per sanctuary seat 21.50
Hospitals                                           per bed            265.50
Institutions (resident)                             per person         265.50
Nursing/rest home                                   per bed            265.50
Laundries (coin operated)                           per machine        265.50
Schools (new independent structures only, excluding per pupil          133.00
new additions)
Restaurants                                         per seat           133.00
Taverns (little food service)                       per seat           133.00
Curb service (drive-ins)                            per car space      133.00
   (c)    Caps. All categories under subsection (b) shall have a cap of
seventy-five units (employees, seats, beds, etc.) or ten thousand dollars
($10,000) whichever is lower.
(Ord. 12-93. Passed 3-15-93.)
   (d)    Where an installation is made that does not conform to one of the
aforesaid categories set out in subsections (a) and (b) hereof, the consulting
engineer for the City shall determine that sewer connection rate upon the
estimated gallons per day discharged into the City sewer system and that the
sewer connection rate shall be five dollars and thirty cents ($5.30) per gallon
of estimated usage. (Ord. 51-91. Passed 7-15-91.)
   923.03 STREET OPENING CHARGES FOR SEWER LATERAL CONNECTIONS.
   The Director of Public Service shall make the following permit charges for
repair and maintenance of the street caused by making the sewer lateral
connection. In lieu of paying this charge, the permit applicant may choose to
repair and maintain the street. Asphalt street repair shall consist of sawing
the street pavement six inches beyond the sewer trench and thereby making a
continuous square pavement edge which will allow the new asphalt to match the
existing asphalt. The repaired portion of the street shall match the grade,
thickness and type of materials of the existing adjacent pavement.
 
Type of Street                       Fee
Dirt streets                         $300.00
Aggregate streets                    375.00
Tar- Bound streets on aggregate base 450.00
Asphalt on aggregate base            450.00
Asphalt on brick and/or concrete     500.00
(Ord. 8-85. Passed 3-14-85.)
   923.04 MINIMUM SEWER CONNECTION PERMIT FEE.
   If none of the above charges are applicable, the Director of Public Service
shall levy a minimum permit fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00).
(Ord. 8-85. Passed 3-14-85.)
   923.05 PRIVATE CONSTRUCTION OF SEWER MAINS; REIMBURSEMENT.
   (a)    The owner or owners of lots or lands who construct a sanitary sewer
main for his or their own use in accordance with the City engineering
specifications, is exempt from the foot frontage assessment. This exemption
shall apply to all succeeding land owners providing the land use for which the
sanitary sewer services were installed does not change. If the land use
changes, the fees in Section
923.02 and/or Section
923.03 shall apply.
   (b)    During a period of ten years, any adjacent property owner who did not
participate in the construction cost of the sanitary sewer, unless the prior
land owner did, and who desires to tap into this line for a sewer lateral shall
reimburse, through the City, the person or persons that paid for the
construction, the sum of fifteen dollars ($15.00) per foot frontage for each
side of the street, or thirty dollars ($30.00) per foot for both sides of the
street.
   (c)    After the ten year period expires, no reimbursements shall be made to
the owners who privately construct the sewers. In lieu of such reimbursement,
the fees in Section
923.02 and Section
923.03 shall be paid to the City and retained by the City.
(Ord. 8-85. Passed 3-14-85.)
   923.06 CITY CONSTRUCTION OF SANITARY SEWERS; CHARGES.
   (a)    If the owner or owners of lots or lands petition the City to
construct a sanitary sewer main for his or their own use in accordance with the
City engineering specifications, the fees in Section
923.02 and Section
923.03 shall be paid to the City, or the sum of fifteen dollars ($15.00) per
front footage for each side of the street or thirty dollars ($30.00) per front
footage for both sides of the street plus those in Section
923.03 shall be paid to the City. The higher cost of the aforementioned fees
will be the applicable fee. Where the sanitary sewer construction costs exceed
the fees to be paid by the front footage method or Section
923.02 schedule times the applicable lots, lands or buildings, the costs not
recovered or having the possibility of not being recovered shall be equally
divided between the City and those land owners who would benefit from the
construction of the sanitary sewer main.
   (b)    The above shall be modified for the following situation: Whenever the
requested sanitary sewer construction serves lots or lands only on one side of
the street, the applicable front footage fee for that situation shall be thirty
dollars ($30.00) per front footage.
   (c)    The fifteen dollar ($15.00) and thirty dollar ($30.00) front footage
costs are estimates of all the costs to install a sanitary sewer main including
manholes, fittings, pavement or right of way repair, engineering, inspection,
legal fees or any other costs directly related to the installation. These costs
shall be used for making the original determination of individual and City
construction costs. After the sanitary sewer main has been installed, a final
cost determination shall be made based upon the actual installation costs.
Individual construction charges and the portion to be paid by the City will
then be adjusted either upward or downward according to the final costs.
   (d)    Upon request of the landowner pursuant to this section, the Director
of Public Service shall determine the estimated cost pursuant to this section,
and shall in writing notify the landowner of the landowner's estimated portion
of the construction cost. Within fifteen days after such notification the
landowner shall deposit with the City a sum equal to the estimated cost. Such
sum shall be deposited in the appropriate construction fund and the landowner
shall be credited with the receipt thereof. Upon completion, the landowner's
portion of the cost shall be paid from the fund. If the actual cost of
construction is less than the estimated cost the Service Director shall cause
the balance of the deposit to be returned to the landowner. If the actual cost
is greater than the estimated cost then the landowner shall remit the entire
balance due before he shall be permitted to connect to the system.
(Ord. 8-85. Passed 3-14-85.)
   923.07 DENIAL OF SEWER EXTENSION REQUESTS.
   The City reserves the right to deny any sanitary sewer extension request, if
in the opinion of Council the economic responsibilities of the City exceed the
funds which the City has available for such extension. (Ord. 8-85. Passed 3-14-
85.)
   923.08 SANITARY SEWER LATERALS.
   Sanitary sewer laterals are considered to be the sole property of the
sanitary sewer user, and as such, it is the individual responsibility of each
user to finance, install according to City ordinances and with approved
materials, maintain and repair the lateral from the sanitary sewer main to the
structure which it serves. (Ord. 54-88. Passed 9-26-88.)
   923.09 WATER PERMIT REQUIRED.
   In order to install a water service and to connect to the City water supply
system or to replace an existing water service line, it shall be necessary to
obtain a water permit from the Director of Public Service who shall issue a
water permit to licensed plumbing contractors only upon the payment of the fees
in Section
923.10 and
923.11 for each connection to the City water distribution system. (Ord. 54-88.
Passed 9-26-88.)

   (d)   Where an installation is made that does not conform to one of the

   923.11 SERVICE LINE AND STREET OPENING CHARGES FOR WATER SERVICE LINE.
   (a)   The Director of Public Service shall make the following permit charges
for the installation of the water service line owned by the City and for the
repair and maintenance of the street caused by making the water service line
connection.
 
Type of Street                   Three-fourths Inch One Inch
Dirt streets                        $450.00            $500.00
Aggregate                           525.00             575.00
Tar-bound streets on aggregate base 600.00             650.00
Asphalt on aggregate base           600.00             650.00
Asphalt on brick and/or concrete    650.00             700.00
   (b)   The charge of one and one-fourth inch and larger water taps or lines
shall be charged to the property owner on the basis of the labor and materials
cost, plus ten percent (10%) of such costs. (Ord. 8-85. Passed 3-14-85.)
   923.12 WATER METERS.
   (a)   All water services shall be metered. When meters are installed under
the provisions of this chapter, the Water Department shall cause the cost of
said meter and meter horn to be billed to the customer. (Ord. 83-99. Passed 12-
6-99.)
   (b)   Where required to be installed, at least one meter shall be installed
for each property. Additional meters may be installed for each tenant,
apartment, separate housing unit or water taker as the Director of Public
Service may deem proper and appropriate; and the property owners shall be held
responsible and liable for the payment of all water consumed upon such
premises. (Ord. 8-85. Passed 3-14-85.)
   923.13 PRIVATE CONSTRUCTION OF WATER LINES; REIMBURSEMENT.
   (a)   The owner or owners of lots or lands who construct a water line for
his or their own use in accordance with the City engineering specification, is
exempt from the foot frontage assessment. This exemption shall apply to all
succeeding land owners providing that the land use for the water services does
not change. If the land use changes, the fees in Sections
923.09 and
923.10 shall apply.
   (b)   During a period of ten years, any adjacent property owner who did not
participate in the construction cost of the water line, unless the prior land
owner did and who desires a tap into this line for a lateral shall reimburse,
through the City, the person or persons that paid for the construction, the sum
of fifteen dollars ($15.00) per foot frontage for each side of the street, or
thirty dollars ($30.00) per foot for both sides of the street.
   (c)   After the ten year period expires, no reimbursements shall be made to
the owners who privately constructed the water line. In lieu of such
reimbursement, the fees in Sections
923.10 and
923.11 shall be paid to the City and retained by the City.
(Ord. 8-85. Passed 3-14-85.)
   923.14 CITY CONSTRUCTION OF WATER LINES; CHARGES.
   (a)   If the owner or owners of lots or lands petition the City to construct
a water line for his or their use in accordance with the City engineering
specifications, the fees in Sections
923.10 and
923.11 shall be paid to the City or the sum of fifteen dollars ($15.00) per
foot frontage for each side of the street or thirty dollars ($30.00) per foot
frontage for both sides of the street shall be paid to the City the higher cost
of the aforementioned fees will be the applicable fee. Where the water line
construction costs exceed the fees to be paid by the front footage method or
Section
923.10 schedule times the applicable lots, lands or buildings, the costs not
recovered or having the possibility of not being recovered shall be equally
divided between the City and those land owners who would benefit from the
construction of the water line.
   (b)   The above shall be modified for the following situation: Whenever the
requested water line construction serves lots or lands only on one side of a
street, the applicable front footage fee for that situation shall be thirty
dollars ($30.00) per foot frontage.
   (c)   The fifteen dollar ($15.00) and thirty dollar ($30.00) front footage
costs are estimates of all the costs to install a Water Main including
manholes, fittings, pavement or right of way repair, engineering, inspection,
legal fees or any other cost directly related to such installation. These costs
shall be used for making the original determination of individual and City
construction costs. After the water main has been installed, a final cost
determination shall be made based upon the actual installation costs.
Individual construction charges and the portion to be paid by the City will
then be adjusted either upward or downward according to the final costs.
   (d)   Upon request of the landowner pursuant to this section, the Director
of Public Service shall determine the estimated cost pursuant to this section
and shall in writing notify the landowner of the landowner’s estimated portion
of the construction cost. Within fifteen days after such notification, the
landowner shall deposit with the City a sum equal to the estimated cost. Such
sum shall be deposited in the appropriate construction fund and the landowner
shall be credited with the receipt thereof. Upon completion, the landowner’s
portion of the cost shall be paid from the fund. If the actual cost of
construction is less than the estimated cost the Service Director shall cause
the balance of the deposit to be returned to the landowner. If the actual cost
is greater than the estimated cost then the landowner shall remit the entire
balance due before he shall be permitted to connect to the system.
(Ord. 8-85. Passed 3-14-85.)
   923.15 DENIAL OF WATER LINE EXTENSIONS.
   The City reserves the right to deny any water line extension request, if in
the opinion of Council, the economic responsibilities of the City exceed the
funds which the City has available for such extension. (Ord. 8-85. Passed 3-14-
85.)
   923.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   Penalty. Any user who is found to have violated an order of Council or
who has failed to comply with any provisions of this chapter and the orders,
rules, regulations and permits issued hereunder, shall be fined. At least a
five hundred dollar ($500.00) fine is mandatory under this section. Each day
during which the violation occurs shall constitute a separate offense.
   (b)   Costs of Damage. Any user violating any of the provisions of this
chapter, or who causes damage or other impairment to the City’s water and/or
wastewater system shall become liable for any expense, loss or damage caused by
the violation. The Director of Public Service may add to the users charges and
fees, the costs assessed for any cleaning, repair or replacement work caused by
the violation. Refusal to pay the assessed costs shall constitute a violation
of this chapter.
   (c)   Falsifying Information. Any person who knowingly makes any false
statements, representation or certification in any application, record, report,
plan or other document filed or required to be maintained pursuant to this
chapter or who falsifies, tampers with or knowingly renders inaccurate any
monitoring or metering device or method required under this chapter shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree.
(Ord. 54-88. Passed 9-26-88.)

1505.07
   925.01 WATER RATES.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Water rates charged to Dover Water Utility customers shall
be as established by Council from time to time.)
   925.011 BILLINGS, PAYMENTS AND PENALTIES.
   All charges for water consumed from the Municipal Waterworks System shall be
billed to the property owner monthly and shall be payable monthly. All final
bills will be determined by the reading on the meter, not the remote. There
shall be a service charge for turn-on for nonpayment of fifteen dollars
($15.00) and a service charge for turn-on after hours at twice the overtime
rate for the workers involved assessed in applicable cases. A five percent (5%)
penalty shall be assessed all customers who fail to pay their water and sewer
bills within fifteen days after such bill becomes due. (Ord. 2-90. Passed 2-5-
90.)
   925.012 WATER METER SERVICES.
   All water services shall be metered. (Ord. 84-99. Passed 12-6-99.)
   925.013 SPACE FOR METER IN NEW CONSTRUCTION.
   Ample space shall be provided inside all new construction for installation
of a water meter. (Ord. 47-81. Passed 11-16-81.)
   925.014 VALVES FOR METER INSTALLATION.
   Where two or more meters are installed on one water service line there shall
be a valve before the meters and a valve after the meters. Where the service
line is larger than 3/4 inch there shall be a valve before and after the
meters. These valves will be installed at the expense of the consumer. (Ord.
47-81. Passed 11-16-81.)
   925.015 BY-PASS WATER LINE FOR WATER METERS.
   Meters of one inch or larger shall have a by-pass water line with proper
valve installation and shall be installed at the expense of the consumer.
(Ord. 47-81. Passed 11-16-81.)
   925.016 INSTALLING REMOTE METER.
   The Water Department, while replacing old meters with a new remote meter or
installing new water meters with remote readers, will install the remote reader
as close as possible to the electric meter. Remote type meters will be
installed wherever possible. It is the intention of the City to meter the
entire City in time with remote water meters and have one meter reader read the
water and electric meters. (Ord. 47-81. Passed 11-16-81.)
   925.017 ACCESS TO WATER METER.
   All consumers of City water shall leave access to the water meter or remote
for repair, replacement or reading of meter. The water meter and remote shall
not be closed in, housed or covered over unless the consumer has the approval
of the Water/Wastewater Superintendent or a representative of the Water
Department. If closed, it shall be changed to the approval of the Water/
Wastewater Superintendent at the consumer’s expense. The Water Department shall
have access to read the water meter at least once each year.
(Ord. 54-88. Passed 9-26-88.)
   925.018 TAPPING CITY DISTRIBUTION WATER MAIN.
   No person or contractor, other than the Water Department shall tap City
distribution water mains for the purpose of running a water service or
services.
(Ord. 47-81. Passed 11-16-81.)
   925.019 BOOSTER PUMPS.
   No person shall install or maintain a water service connection to any
premises where a booster pump has been installed on the service line to or
within such premises, unless such booster pump is equipped with a low pressure
cut-off designed to shut-off the booster pump when the pressure in the service
line on the suction side of the pump drops to ten pounds per square inch gauge
or less. (Ord. 47-81. Passed 11-16-81.)
   925.020 YARD HYDRANTS.
   The installation of yard hydrants where water is available or accessible for
drinking or culinary purposes and having drip openings below ground surface is
prohibited unless such hydrants are equipped with approved devices to prevent
entrance of ground water into chambers connected with the water supply.
(Ord. 47-81. Passed 11-16-81.)
   925.021 LAYING WATER MAINS.
   Water mains shall be laid at least ten feet horizontally from any sanitary
sewer, storm sewer or sewer manhole.
   Water mains crossing storm or sanitary sewers shall have a separation of at
least eighteen inches between the bottom of the water main and the top of the
sewer.
(Ord. 47-81. Passed 11-16-81.)
   925.025 RATES; FIRE SPRINKLING SYSTEM; FIRE LINES.
   The following rates for service lines installed for sprinkler systems or
fire lines for fire protection connected off of City water lines shall be
charged and collected from the property owner regardless of whether or not the
water meter is in operation on the premises:
Service (inches) Per Bimonthly Period
Two              $7.20
Three            12.00
Four             28.12
Six              45.00
Eight            72.60
Ten              118.80
Twelve           138.00
(Ord. 16-81. Passed 4-20-81.)
   925.03 WATER SERVICE OUTSIDE CITY LIMITS.
   (a)   The sale of City water to customers outside of the City corporation
limits shall be permitted.
   (b)   All sales of City water made outside of the City corporation limits,
for new and existing services, shall be at a rate of one and one-half times the
rate of customers within the City corporation limits. (Ord. 14-97. Passed 3-17-
97.)
   925.04 WATER-CONSUMING DEVICES; WATER OUTLET. (REPEALED)
   EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
925.04 was repealed by Ordinance 84-99, passed December 6, 1999
   925.05 (RESERVED)
   925.06 TIME OF SPRINKLING.
   Every person, firm or corporation served by or connected to the Municipal
Water Works System may sprinkle or water grass, lawns, gardens, plants,
foliage, trees or other objects by the use of a hand hose, sprinkler or any
device, between May 1st and October 15th of each year.
   (a)   Restrictions:
      (1)   During a water emergency.
      (2)   During a drought situation.
      (3)   Any other situation deemed necessary by the administration.
   (b)   Restriction Levels:
      (1)   Voluntary conservation.
      (2)   Time restrictions.
      (3)   Total water sprinkling restrictions.
(Ord. 85-99. Passed 12-6-99.)
   925.07 PLACES FOR COLLECTION ESTABLISHED.
   Council deems it necessary to establish places in the City for the purposes
of collecting water, sewer, and trash bills due the Utility Department of the
City.
(Ord. 50-84. Passed 9-17-84.)
   925.08 DESIGNATION OF PLACES AND AGENTS.
   To carry out such collections, it is necessary for Council to designate
agents or places where the water, sewer, and trash bills may be paid and to
provide that certain qualifications shall be set up by the Utility Department
subject to the approval of Council before any person, firm or corporation shall
be designated as a collecting agent. (Ord. 50-84. Passed 9-17-84.)
   925.09 APPLICATION.
   Any corporation desiring to collect water, sewer, and trash bills for the
City shall file an application with the Clerk of Council. The application shall
be in writing signifying that the applicant wishes to be designated as an agent
for the purpose of collecting water, sewer and trash bills. The application
shall then be read to Council at its next regular meeting and accepted or
rejected by Council within thirty days thereafter. Failure to take any action
shall be deemed as a rejection. (Ord. 50-84. Passed 9-17-84.)
   925.10 DISPOSITION OF MONEY COLLECTED.
   All moneys collected by a designated agent shall be paid over daily to the
Utility Department and complete settlement made each day. In addition to the
water, sewer, and trash fees collected, the designated agent may collect a
transaction fee provided that such fee is approved by Council prior to the
transaction fee being assessed the customer. Any increase in such fees shall
also be presented to Council for approval thirty days prior to enactment of
such increase. (Ord. 50-84. Passed 9-17-84.)
   925.11 RIGHTS OF AGENT.
   Any agent designated by Council shall continue as such collecting agent only
during the pleasure of the Council of the City, and the agency may be
terminated without notice by Council for any reason whatsoever and the
collecting agent shall not be considered to have any vested interest or
property right insofar as the City is concerned, and the agency shall not be
assignable or passed as a property right. (Ord. 1577. Passed 1-25-43.)
   925.12 HANDLING OF FUNDS; AGREEMENT TO TERMS.
   (a)   All moneys collected by the designated agent shall be kept separate
and apart from any personal funds of the collecting agent and in the event any
controversies shall arise between the collecting agent and any person, firm, or
corporation regarding the payment or nonpayment of their bill to the collecting
agent, the agent shall indemnify and save harmless the City from any loss
arising under such situation.
   (b)   Agent shall agree by an agreement entered into within thirty days of
its designation as a collecting agent by resolution of Council to all of the
terms and conditions set forth in Sections
925.07 through
925.13. Such agreement shall be maintained on file in the Utility Office and
will be available for public inspection during normal working hours. The
agreement shall include a provision regarding the liability of the agent to the
City in the event that such conditions are not fulfilled. (Ord. 50-84. Passed
9-17-84.)
   925.13 DESIGNATION OF COLLECTING AGENT; RESOLUTION BY COUNCIL.
   Council shall by resolution designate a collecting agent, the resolution to
become part of the permanent records of Council and the designation shall be
revoked by resolution.
(Ord. 1577. Passed 1-25-43.)
   925.14 OWNER TO MAINTAIN PRIVATE WATER LINES.
   (a)   Every owner or occupant of lands, lots, buildings, or premises served
by or connected to the Municipal Waterworks System of the City, must maintain
and keep in a state of good repair all private waterlines upon his property or
over which he has control.
   (b)   If the superintendent of the water department, upon inspection or
complaint, determines that a private waterline has not been maintained as
stated in subsection (a) above or that water, for any reason, is leaking from
waterlines under the control of said property owners, he shall notify the
property owner to repair said leaking waterlines within ten days of the receipt
of said notice.
   (c)   The notice referred to in subsection (b) above shall be by certified
mail return receipt requested and shall be served upon the owner or occupant of
the premises.
(Ord. 56-76. Passed 6-7-76.)
   (d)   If the owner or occupant fails to repair such waterline within ten
days of receipt of the notice, the Water Department shall discontinue service
to that property until such time as the Water Department is notified by the
property owner of the repair to such line.
(Ord. 54-88. Passed 9-26-88.)
   925.15 BACKFLOW PREVENTION.
   (a)   If in the judgment of the Water/Wastewater Superintendent, an approved
backflow prevention device is necessary for the safety of the public water
system, the Water/Wastewater Superintendent or his representative will give
notice to the water consumer to install such an approved device immediately.
The water consumer shall, at his own expense, install such an approved device
at a location and in a manner approved by the Water/Wastewater Superintendent
and shall have inspections and tests made of such approved devices as required
by the Water/Wastewater Superintendent.
   (b)   No person, firm or corporation shall establish or permit to be
established or maintain or permit to be maintained any connection whereby a
private, auxiliary or emergency water supply other than the regular public
water supply of the City may enter the supply or distributing system of the
City unless such private, auxiliary or emergency water supply and the method of
connection and use of such supply shall have been approved by the Water/
Wastewater Superintendent and by the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency.
   (c)   It shall be the duty of the Water/Wastewater Superintendent to cause
surveys and investigations to be made of industrial and other properties served
by the public water supply where actual or potential hazards to the public
water supply may exist. Such surveys and investigations shall be made a matter
of public record and shall be repeated as often as the Water/Wastewater
Superintendent shall deem necessary.
   (d)   The Water/Wastewater Superintendent or his or the City’s duly
authorized representative shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time
any property served by a connection to the public water supply or distributing
system of the City for the purpose of inspecting the piping system or systems
thereof. On demand the owner, lessees or occupant of any property so served
shall furnish to the Water/Wastewater Superintendent any information which he
may request regarding the piping system or systems or water use on such
property. The refusal of such information when demanded shall, within the
discretion of the Water/Wastewater Superintendent be deemed evidence of the
presence of improper connections as provided in this section.
   (e)   The Water/Wastewater Superintendent is hereby authorized and directed
to discontinue, after reasonable notice to the occupant thereof, the water
service to any property wherein any connection in violation of the provisions
of this section is known to exist, and to take such other precautionary
measures as he may deem necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of
the public water supply distribution mains. Water service to such property
shall not be restored until such conditions shall have been eliminated or
corrected in compliance with the provisions of this section.
(Ord. 38-81. Passed 9-21-81; Ord. 54-88. Passed 9-26-88.)
   925.16 CONNECTION TO MUNICIPAL WATER SUPPLY.
   (a)   All plumbing fixtures in a private dwelling structure shall be
supplied with running water from the Municipal water supply system.
(Ord. 34-96. Passed 7-1-96.)
   (b)   The drilling and establishment of private or public water supply wells
(as defined in Ohio R.C. 3701.344) shall be permitted for purposes other than
human consumption (i.e., irrigation, manufactured cooling purposes, etc.). No
physical connections between private water well lines and water lines supplied
by the Municipal water supply system shall be permitted. (Ord. 56-96. Passed
11-4-96.)
   (c)   Anyone planning to drill a private water well within the Municipal
limits of the City of Dover shall apply for a permit through the office of the
Director of Public Service and pay a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for each
permit.
   (d)   All existing private and public water wells within the Municipal
limits of the City of Dover at the time of passage of this section shall be
registered with the Director of Public Service within one year of the date of
this section.
(Ord. 34-96. Passed 7-1-96.)
   925.17 WATER ON AND OFF FEE.
   A charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be assessed by the City for
any non-emergency water turned off or on. This fee is not applicable for any
repair of water service.
(Ord. 86-99. Passed 12-6-99.)
   925.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   Any user who violates the provisions of Section
925.05 and/or
925.06 shall, for a first offense be fined fifty dollars ($50.00). For a second
offense, the fine shall be one hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00). For a
third and subsequent offense, the fine shall be two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00). Each day during which the violation occurs shall constitute a
separate offense.
   (b)   Penalty. Any user who is found to have violated any other order of
Council or who has failed to comply with any other provisions of this chapter
and the orders, rules, regulations and permits issued hereunder, shall be
fined. At least a five hundred dollar ($500.00) fine is mandatory under this
section. Each day during which the violation occurs shall constitute a separate
offense.
   (c)   Costs of Damage. Any user violating any of the provisions of this
chapter, or who causes damage or other impairment to the City’s water system
shall become liable for any expense, loss or damage caused by the violation.
The Director of Public Service may add to the users charges and fees, the costs
assessed for any cleaning, repair or replacement work caused by the violation.
Refusal to pay the assessed costs shall constitute a violation of this chapter.
   (d)   Falsifying Information. Any person who knowingly makes any false
statements, representation or certification in any application, record, report,
plan or other document filed or required to be maintained pursuant to this
chapter or who falsifies, tampers with or knowingly renders inaccurate any
monitoring or metering device or method required under this chapter shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree.
(Ord. 54-88. Passed 9-26-88.)

   926.02 DECLARATION OF NECESSITY.
   Council hereby declares it necessary to recover from all users of the water
system, whether inside the City or outside its boundaries, the sum of money
annually required to amortize debts incurred by the City to construct and
provide improvements to the water system.
(Ord. 41-94. Passed 9-19-94.)
   926.03 FUND ESTABLISHED.
   All moneys collected from charges established herein shall be deposited in a
Water Improvement Fund, commonly referred to as "Debt Service Fund". The moneys
in this Fund shall be used for the cost and expense of "debt service".
(Ord. 41-94. Passed 9-19-94.)
   926.04 DEBT SERVICE CHARGES DETERMINATION.
   The Auditor shall determine the sum of money required to provide for the
annual payments of debt service and recommend any adjustments in the rate to
Council as needed.
(Ord. 41-94. Passed 9-19-94.)
   926.05 WATER SYSTEM IMPROVEMENT CHARGES FOR USERS.
   Anyone connected to the City water system shall pay a monthly debt service
charge of five dollars and ninety-five cents ($5.95) per single family unit
equivalent. The definition of single family unit equivalent shall be as given
in Section
926.01.
(Ord. 41-94. Passed 9-19-94.)
   926.06 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Service Director shall make and enforce such rules and regulations as
may be deemed necessary for the enforcement of the provisions hereof, including
periodic adjustment of rates, for the proper determination and collection on
the rates and charges herein provided for the economical management of the
system. Such rules and regulations, when not repugnant to existing ordinances
of the City or laws of the State, shall have the same force and effect as
ordinance of Council.
(Ord. 41-94. Passed 9-19-94.)
   926.07 PAYMENT OF CHARGES.
   The charges herein provided shall be due and payable under all the
requirements of Chapter
925.
(Ord. 41-94. Passed 9-19-94.)
